text:
And after: When I decided to reprint my book "Hijab al-Mar'ah al-Muslimah" (The Veil of the Muslim Woman) - after several years had passed and it had been printed several times via offset photography - I saw that I must review it again, hoping I might be inspired to add new benefits to it, in addition to what had accumulated with me over time. I placed each item in my copy in its proper place over the days, and corrected inevitable typographical or intellectual errors that hardly any book escapes. I paid special attention to reading the books and treatises authored in this era regarding women - which number in the dozens - that had gathered with me. I found most of them had followed one another in refuting me, some directly naming the book and its author, and some addressing the issue directly without mentioning my person. This is the issue regarding which one of the doctors claimed that I was unique in asserting it, to the exclusion of those before me among the scholars of the Salaf (predecessors) and the Khalaf (successors); namely: that the woman's face is not 'Awrah (private parts to be concealed) and that it is not obligatory for her to cover it. I saw - by Allah - a great wonder in their consensus on the statement of obligation (Wujub), their imitation (Taqlid) of one another in that, their method of inferring evidence from narration (Riwayah) or understanding (Dirayah) that is not authentic, and their interpretation of texts that contradict them from the Salafi tracks (Athar) and the famous sayings of some of the followed Imams, ignoring them as if they were nothing mentioned. This made me feel that all of them - regrettably - wrote what they wrote while surrendering to human emotions, personal impulses, and local traditions, not in submission to the legal (Sharia) evidences. For the evidences they mentioned [6]

- according to their school of thought (Madhhab) - they know very well were not hidden from me, because they saw them in my book along with the answers to them and the deduction using evidence that contradicts them, which is more authentic to us than their deductions they clung to. Just as they know that I do not deny the legitimacy of the researches: However, it is necessary to point out the most important researches that I dealt with in the Introduction referred to (1), summarizing the discussion therein as much as possible. So I say:

The First Research: The Verse of the Hijab: ({...to bring down over themselves [part] of their outer garments (Jilbabs)}) [Al-Ahzab: 59]

text: 1 - The strict opponents regarding women - foremost among them Hamoud at-Tuwayjiri, may Allah preserve him - insist that the meaning of (yudnina / bring down) is: that they cover their faces. This is contrary to the meaning of the root of this word: "Al-Idna'" in the language, which is "bringing close" (Al-Taqreeb), as I had mentioned and explained in the Book (1) - as will appear in its place therein - and I clarified that it is not a textual stipulation for covering the face, and that the opponents must bring forth what makes their view preponderant. This is something they have not done and will not be able to do, except for defaming those who oppose them among those who followed the Salaf of the Ummah, their exegetes (Mufassirin), and their scholars. Here is Imam Al-Raghib Al-Isfahani saying in "Al-Mufradat": "(Dana) Al-Dunuw: Nearness... and it is said: I brought the two matters close (danaytu) and I brought one of them close (adnaytu)

And this is how the Interpreter of the Qur'an, Abdullah bin Abbas, interpreted it in what is authentically reported from him, for he said: "She draws the Jilbab close to her face but does not strike [cover] with it," as its extraction (Takhrij) will come later. Here is Sheikh At-Tuwayjiri - may Allah guide us and him - saying at the end of his mentioned book (p. 249): "And whoever permits Sufoor (uncovering the face) for women (meaning uncovering the face only) - and uses as evidence the likes of what Al-Albani used - has indeed opened the door of Tabarruj (display of beauty) wide open and emboldened women to commit the reprehensible acts that uncovered women do today." Thus he said - may Allah reform and guide him - for this attack and defamation does not affect me alone, but also strikes those who are my role models and predecessors (Salaf) among the Companions, the Tabi'in, the exegetes, the jurists, and others - whom we mentioned in the Book - as will come, and in the Introduction referred to as well. Suffice for me now one example from them, which is what came in "Al-Insaf fi Ma'rifat Ar-Rajih min Al-Khilaf 'ala Madhhab Al-Imam Al-Mubajjal Ahmad ibn Hanbal" by Sheikh Ala' al-Din al-Mirdawi (1 / 452): "The correct view of the Madhhabs is that the face is not part of the 'Awrah." Then he mentioned the same regarding the hands. It is the choice of Ibn Qudamah Al-Maqdisi in "Al-Mughni" (1 / 637), and he used as evidence for his choice the prohibition of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, for the woman in Ihram to wear gloves and the Niqab, and said: [8]

book_title: The Silencing Response to those who opposed the scholars, became strict and fanatical, and obligated the woman to cover her face and hands, and made it mandatory, and were not content with their saying: It is a Sunnah and recommended
text: "If the face and hands were 'Awrah, covering them would not have been forbidden. And because the need calls for uncovering the face for buying and selling, and the hands for taking and giving." This is what he relied upon and asserted in his book "Al-Umdah" (66). So what is the opinion of Sheikh At-Tuwayjiri regarding this text from this glorious Hanbali Imam? Do you think he is a caller to Sufoor as well and an opener of the door of Tabarruj wide open and...? Do you not fear, O Sheikh, that the threat of his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, might encompass you: (Authentic) "Indeed, a servant may speak a word, not clarifying it (its implications), by which he falls into the Fire farther than the distance between the East and the West." Extracted by the two Sheikhs (Bukhari and Muslim) from the hadith of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, and it is extracted in "As-Sahihah" (2 / 540). If the Sheikh - may Allah guide him - had presented his opinion to the people and defended it with authentic Sharia evidences, we would have said: Welcome to it, whether he was right or wrong. But for him to unleash his "Rigorous Sword" (Sarim) upon those who opposed him in his opinion and use it to defame even the "Glass Vessels" (women) - whom the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, commanded to be treated gently - merely because they disagreed with him and followed the correct view of his "Madhhab" which he turned away from due to an obsession that overcame him, then this is a moral calamity and another doctrinal violation. For Imam Ahmad, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him, said: "It is not appropriate for a jurist to compel people to his Madhhab" (1).

book_title: The Silencing Response to those who opposed the scholars, became strict and fanatical, and obligated the woman to cover her face and hands, and made it mandatory, and were not content with their saying: It is a Sunnah and recommended
text: The Second Research: Many of the strict opponents claim: That the (Jilbab) commanded in the verse of Al-Ahzab is synonymous with the (Hijab) mentioned in the other verse: ({And when you ask [his wives] for something, ask them from behind a partition (Hijab)}) [Al-Ahzab: 53]. This is a strange confusion driven by their knowledge that the first verse contains no evidence that the face and hands are 'Awrah, unlike the other one, for it concerns the woman while she is in her home, as she is not usually wearing a Jilbab or Khimar inside, so she does not appear to the asker, contrary to what some women do today who have no morals. Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah drew attention to this difference, saying in "Al-Fatawa" (15 / 448): "So the verse of the Jilbabs is regarding outer garments when emerging from the dwellings, and the verse of the Hijab is regarding conversing inside the dwellings." I say: There is nothing in either of the two verses that indicates the obligation of covering the face and hands. As for the first, it is because the Jilbab is the sheet that a woman wraps herself with over her clothes - and not over her face - as is mentioned later in the Book (p. 83). Upon this constitute all the books of language; there is no mention of the face in any of them at all. It has been authentically reported from Ibn Abbas that he said in its interpretation: "She draws the Jilbab close to her face but does not strike [cover] with it." Extracted by Abu Dawood in his "Masa'il" (p. 110). Anything contradicting it is either Shadh (irregular) or Da'if (weak). The detail is in that Introduction [10]

text:
As for the other verse, it is for what I mentioned previously. For this reason, it appeared to me to make the title of the book: "Jilbab Al-Mar'ah..." (The Jilbab of the Woman...) because it is more pertinent to the subject of the book, as is apparent. And Allah the Exalted is the Granter of success.

The Third Research: Among their contradictions is that - while they obligate the woman to cover her face - they permit her to uncover her left eye, and some were lenient and said: both eyes, based on some flimsy traces (Athar), among which is the Hadith of Ibn Abbas coming in the Book (p. 88). However, what contradicts it has been narrated from him with the wording: "And bringing down the Jilbab is that she puts it on as a veil (taqanna') and tightens it on her forehead." This is the textual proof of our saying: That it does not include the face. Therefore, all the opponents concealed it and did not mention it, even though it has a weak chain, but it has witnessing reports as will come. Truthful is he who said: The People of Sunnah mention what is for them and what is against them, and the People of Desires mention what is for them and do not mention what is against them. From that is that Sheikh Abdul Qadir Al-Sindi concealed in his treatise "Al-Hijab" one of the two defects of the first report of Ibn Abbas and downplayed the significance of the other (p. 19 - 20). The author of "Ya Fatat al-Islam" was deceived by him and declared its authenticity (p. 252), and likewise the author of "Fiqh al-Nazar fi al-Islam" authenticated it (p. 65). Worse than that is what the one named (Darwish) did in what he called "Fasl al-Khitab", where he changed its chain of transmission in two places (46 and 82), making it from the narration of Muhammad bin Sirin from Ibn Abbas. This is a sheer fabrication with no basis [11]

text: from this narration. I do not know if this was intentional on his part or an oversight? I would have liked to lean towards the first of the two, had I not seen another fabrication of his (p. 82) which I might point out on another occasion, Allah the Exalted willing. It seems to me that they - feeling the weakness of their argument deep in their souls - resort to using opinion and the language of emotions - or what resembles philosophy - saying: "The most beautiful thing in a woman is her face, so it is unreasonable that it is permissible for her to uncover it." It was said to them: "And the most beautiful thing in the face is the eyes, so blind them then, and order her to cover them with her Jilbab." It was said to them by way of opposition: "And the most beautiful thing in a man - regarding the woman - is his face, so order the men also - by this philosophy of yours - to cover their faces as well in front of women, especially those among them of surpassing beauty," as reported in the biography of Abu Al-Hasan the Preacher known as (Al-Masri): "He had a gathering where he spoke and preached, and men and women attended his preaching gathering. He used to place a Burqa (veil) over his face, fearing that women would be tempted by the beauty of his face." "Tarikh Baghdad" (12 / 75 - 76). So what does the virtuous Sheikh At-Tuwayjiri say - and those who run behind him among the philosophizers - is what this Egyptian did legislated (mashru') or not? Knowing that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was more beautiful than him and did not do his deed. If you say it is legislated, you have opposed the Sunnah of your Prophet and have gone astray, and this is not what we hope for you. And if you say it is not - as is expected of you - you are correct, and your philosophy is void, and you must retract it and suffice in your refutation of me with the evidences [12]

Otherwise, you crowd yourselves among the (People of Opinion/Ra'y), as Ahmad narrated in "Al-'Ilal" (2 / 246) from Hammad bin Salamah who said: "Abu Hanifa received the Athar (traces) and Sunan (traditions) and rejected them with his opinion."

The Fourth Research: The Khimar and I'tijar and His saying Almighty: ({and to draw their headcovers (Khumur) over their chests (Juyub)}) [An-Nur: 31]. We mentioned later in the Book (p. 72) that the Khimar is: The covering of the head only, excluding the face. I cited the words of some scholars as evidence for that: such as Ibn Al-Athir and Ibn Kathir. But Sheikh At-Tuwayjiri - and those who followed him among the adherents of Madhhabs and imitators - refused that and insisted that it includes the face as well, and repeated that in various places. They clung in that to some statements that amount to no more than a scholar's slip, or a slip of the pen, or at best an interpretation of intent and not an interpretation of the word, which should not be relied upon in the place of dispute and disagreement (1). At the same time, he turned away from the definitive evidences from the Book and the Sunnah and the sayings of the scholars and Imams from the exegetes, Muhaddithin, jurists, and linguists contradicting him, some of which appeared in his own book, but he passed over them and concealed their indication with deep regret. For instance, when he cited the verse: ({And women of post-menstrual age who have no desire for marriage - there is no blame upon them for putting aside their outer garments...}) [An-Nur: 60] the verse, and spoke about it for about two pages (161 - 163) with useful speech, but he did not clarify to his readers what is meant by the quotes he mentioned in interpreting: (their garments / thiyabahunna) as being the Jilbab. Among them his saying: Abu Salih said: She puts aside the Jilbab and stands before the man in the Dir' (chemise) and the Khimar. And Sa'id bin Jubayr said: There is no harm for her to lay aside [garments] in the presence of a stranger or others, provided there is a thick Khimar upon her. A group of Hanbalis and others stated this explicitly. Ibn Al-Jawzi mentioned in "Zad Al-Masir" (6 / 63) from Abu Ya'la - meaning: the Hanbali Judge - that he said: In this verse is evidence that it is permissible for the old woman to uncover her face and hands before men. Similar is in Ahkam Al-Quran by Al-Jassas (3 / 334). Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah indicated this meaning in "Tafsir Surat An-Nur" (p. 57) and At-Tuwayjiri quoted it (167) using it as proof. All of this indicates that these virtuous scholars of the Salaf and Khalaf view that the Khimar does not cover the face, but rather the head only, as is our saying. Whoever contemplates some of the Sheikh's labored answers will be certain that he sees this with us, but he argues, stubbornly resists, and conceals. Look, for example, at his answer regarding the hadith of Jabir coming in the Book (p. 60) which contains: "That he saw a woman with darkening on her cheeks" [14]

text: narrated without his saying: "That he saw a woman..." until the end. So the Sheikh answered (p. 208) with the possibility that "that woman was of post-menstrual age..." meaning: so uncovering her face is permissible, as explicitly stated by Sheikh Ibn Uthaymeen in his "Risalah" (p. 32). As for At-Tuwayjiri, he speaks in riddles and obscures, and does not clarify to his reader. So is this answer valid from the Sheikh while he insists that the Khimar covers the face as well? May Allah guide you. Know that the purpose of mentioning this verse of (The Post-Menstrual Women) is only to establish the argument against the Sheikh using what he adopted of the scholars' sayings in interpreting: (their garments) as being the (Jilbab) and that it is permissible for (The Post-Menstrual Women) to appear with her Khimar "in the presence of foreign men" seeing her face. The meaning of this according to them - and the Sheikh is a follower of them in this - is that the Khimar linguistically does not cover the face. This alone is sufficient as an argument against the Sheikh, may Allah the Exalted guide him. How then if there is added to that what will come from the Sunnah and the sayings of the scholars in every science, making the Sheikh contrary to their consensus and following other than their path? I say this to remind that there is another saying in interpreting: (their garments) - which I had mentioned in its place in the Book - which is the Khimar, and it is the more authentic view from Ibn Abbas as will come (p. 110 - 111). The Sheikh concealed this saying as is his habit regarding what does not agree with his desire, contrary to the People of Sunnah who mention what is for them and what is against them as preceded. Since he has chosen the first saying, which is (the Jilbab), he is required to say that (the Khimar) does not cover the face, and that is the intent. Ibn al-Qattan al-Fasi chose the other saying in "Al-Nazar fi Ahkam Al-Nazar", saying (Folio 35 / 2): [15]

text: "The garments mentioned are the Khimar and the Jilbab; it is permitted for her to go out without them and appear to men... And this is the saying of Rabi'ah bin Abdur-Rahman. And this is the more apparent view, for the verse only granted concession in laying aside a garment which, if a woman of adornment laid it aside, she might display beauty (tabarruj)..." to the end of his speech, which is very precious. Were it not that the space does not allow expansion, I would have quoted it in its entirety, for I have not seen it from anyone else. As for his opposition to the Sunnah, it is frequent, including his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: (Authentic) "Allah does not accept the prayer of a menstruating woman (adult) except with a Khimar" (1). It is an authentic hadith extracted in "Al-Irwa" (196) via the narration of a group including Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban in their "Sahihs" (2).

text: So does Sheikh At-Tuwayjiri say that it is obligatory for the adult woman to cover her face in prayer? Similar to it is his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, regarding the woman who vowed to perform Hajj bareheaded (hasirah): (Authentic) "Order her to ride, to wear a Khimar, and to perform Hajj." And in a narration: "and cover her hair." It is also authentic, I extracted it in "Al-Ahadith As-Sahihah" (2930). Does the Sheikh permit the woman in Ihram to strike her Khimar over her face while he knows his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: "The woman in Ihram does not wear Niqab..."? Similar to that are the hadiths of wiping over the Khimar in Wudu (ablution), performed by him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and ordered for men and women. So who is the one who holds the Sheikh's opinion which contradicts the Qur'an, the Sunnah, and the sayings of the scholars as well, as preceded in the interpretation of the verse of the post-menstrual women? We have more as will come. From that is the saying of the erudite scholar Al-Zabidi in "Sharh Al-Qamus" (3 / 189) regarding the saying of Umm Salamah, may Allah be pleased with her: That she used to wipe over the Khimar. Extracted by Ibn Abi Shaybah in "Al-Musannaf" (1 / 22): She meant by (Al-Khimar): The Turban (Al-Imamah), because the man covers his head with it just as the woman covers it with her Khimar. [17]

book_title: The Silencing Response to those who opposed the scholars, became strict and fanatical, and obligated the woman to cover her face and hands, and made it mandatory, and were not content with their saying: It is a Sunnah and recommended
text:
Likewise in "Lisan Al-Arab" and in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Wasit" - authored by a committee of scholars under the supervision of the "Arabic Language Academy" - is the text: (Al-Khimar): Everything that covers. And from it is the Khimar of the woman, which is a cloth with which she covers her head. And from it is the Turban (Al-Imamah) because the man covers his head with it and winds it under the chin (tahneek). These are explicit texts from these scholars that the Khimar for the woman is like the Turban for the man. Just as the Turban when mentioned generally does not mean covering the man's face, likewise the Khimar when mentioned generally does not mean covering the woman's face with it. Upon this proceeded the scholars of various specializations among: Exegetes, Muhaddithin, Jurists, Linguists, and others, past and present. It was facilitated for me to stand upon the words of more than forty of them; I mentioned their texts in the research referred to in the Introduction, and all of them agreed on mentioning the head without the face in their definition of the Khimar. Are these pillars [of knowledge] - O Sheikh - mistaken - and they are the people whose follower is not miserable - and you are correct?

text: 4 - From the Linguists: Al-Raghib Al-Isfahani (d. 502) said in his unique book "Al-Mufradat fi Gharib al-Quran" (p. 159): "(Khamara) The origin of Khamr is: covering a thing. I do not rule out that those who dared to oppose those preceding texts from the Book, the Sunnah, and the sayings of the Imams indicating that (Al-Khimar) is the headcover without the circle of her face, might say that. text: "Ibn Al-Athir said: And in the hadith of Abdullah bin Adi bin Al-Khiyar: He came while wearing an I'tijar with his turban; Wahshi saw nothing of him except his eyes and his feet. I'tijar with the turban: is that he wraps it on his head and returns its end over his face and does not make anything of it go under his chin. End quote." I say: This does not contradict what preceded from the language scholars regarding the explanation of (Al-I'tijar), because what Ibn Al-Athir said is explicitly stated in the hadith: "Nothing was seen of him except his eyes." So it is a revealing description of (Al-I'tijar) and not inherent to it. Just as if someone said: (He came wearing a Khimar or a Turban, nothing was seen of him except his eyes). That does not mean to anyone who understands the language that among the necessities of Ikhtimar and Ta'ammum (wearing turban) is covering the face except the eyes. Therefore, Al-Hafiz did not add in "Al-Fath" (7 / 369) to his saying: "(Mu'tajiran) i.e., winding his turban on his head without Tahneek (passing under the chin)." The summary of the matter: Khimar and I'tijar when mentioned generally only mean: covering the head. So whoever adds covering the face to that is stubborn and obstinate against the preceding evidences. Accordingly, the inference of the Sheikh - and those who imitated him - using the hadiths that contain women wearing Khimar or I'tijar for his false claim religiously and linguistically falls. At the same time, our inference using the verse of (Al-Khimar) and the hadith of Fatimah coming on (p. 66) No. (5) that the woman's face is not 'Awrah stands valid, as will be explained there. And Allah is the One sought for help. (See the hadith of Aisha regarding the women Emigrants wearing Khimar later [25]

text: "O Asma, indeed when a woman reaches menstruation, it is not correct that anything be seen of her except this and this. And he pointed to his face and his hands" (1): In it is evidence for those who say: It is permissible to look at a foreign woman. Ibn Raslan said: And this is when there is safety from Fitnah (temptation) regarding what desire calls for, such as intercourse or less than that. But when there is fear of Fitnah, the apparent general meaning of the verse and hadith is that necessity is not a condition. And what indicates restricting it to necessity is the agreement of Muslims on preventing women from going out with uncovered faces, especially when corrupt people are many. Al-Qadi Iyad related from the scholars: That it is not obligatory on her to cover her face in her path, and men must lower their gaze according to the verse. The disagreement on the root of the issue has preceded. I say: He refers to a research of his in the chapter preceding the aforementioned hadith of Aisha, where he explained the verse: ({and not to display their adornment except what is apparent thereof}) [An-Nur: 31] and quoted under it Al-Zamakhshari's interpretation of adornment in it, including his saying: "So what was apparent of it like the ring, kohl, and dye, there is no harm in revealing it to strangers." Then Ash-Shawkani said following it: "The result: That a woman reveals of the places of adornment what necessity calls for

This is assuming no Marfu' (Prophetic) interpretation has been narrated. And in the chapter following this one, there will come what indicates that the face and hands are among what is excepted." So contemplate, O noble reader, is the issue a matter of consensus as the Sheikh said first? And was he honest in his quotation of Ibn Raslan's speech and then Ash-Shawkani's speech second? Who adopted what the hadith of Aisha indicated, which we strengthened in the Book (p. 57 - 60), just as Majd al-Din Ibn Taymiyyah (may Allah have mercy on him) adopted it by titling it "Chapter: That the woman is 'Awrah except the face and hands." As for the Sheikh, he weakened it with a stroke of a pen - as they say - and did not turn to the witnessing report, the practice of the Salaf, and the strengthening by Al-Hafiz Al-Bayhaqi and others as will come. So he closed his eyes to all of that out of arrogance, stubbornness, and insolence, and more than one of the imitating writers became entangled with him in this issue. And the other of his two texts: His saying in some of his answers (p. 243): "The truth is with the Sheikhs who hold that the woman's face is 'Awrah which she is not allowed to uncover before foreign men, and their evidence for that is the Book, the Sunnah, and the Consensus." 
[28].

Invalidity of the Consensus he claimed: So I say, seeking help from Allah alone: No one from the people of knowledge has uttered the word "Consensus" in this issue, as far as I know and my knowledge encompasses, except this Sheikh. Nothing drove him to that except his strictness and fanaticism for his opinion and his closing of his eyes to everything that contradicts him from the texts. For the disagreement in it is old; no book specializing in discussing differences is devoid of it. Had I ample time, I would have authored a special treatise in which I would list what was facilitated for me of their sayings on this issue. But I must quote here some of them that indicate the invalidity of the consensus he claimed. So I say:

The First: Ibn Hazm said in his book "Maratib Al-Ijma" (p. 29) verbatim: "And they agreed that the hair of the free woman and her body, except for her face and hands, are 'Awrah, and they disagreed regarding the face and hands, even their fingernails, are they 'Awrah or not?" Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah approved this in his commentary on it and did not critique him as he did in some other places.

The Second: Ibn Hubayra Al-Hanbali said in "Al-Ifsah" (1 / 118 - Aleppo): "And they disagreed regarding the 'Awrah of the free woman alone. Abu Hanifa said: All of her is 'Awrah except the face, the hands, and the feet. And it was narrated from him that her feet are 'Awrah. And Malik [29] and Al-Shafi'i said: All of her is 'Awrah except her face and hands. This is the saying of Ahmad in one of his two narrations. The other narration: All of her is 'Awrah except her face specifically. And this is the famous one and Al-Khiraqi chose it. He missed a third narration which is: That all of her is 'Awrah even her fingernail. As will come with the clarification of Ibn Abd al-Barr's refutation of it shortly.

The Third: It came in the book "Al-Fiqh 'ala Al-Madhahib Al-Arba'a" (Jurisprudence according to the Four Schools) authored by a committee of scholars including Al-Jaziri in the discussion of the limit of the woman's 'Awrah (1 / 167 - Second Edition): "However, if she is in the presence of a foreign man or a non-Muslim woman, her 'Awrah is her entire body except the face and the hands, for they are not 'Awrah (1), so looking at them is permissible when there is safety from Fitnah." Then he excepted from that the Shafi'i Madhhab, and there is an apparent objection to this due to what preceded in "Al-Ifsah" and others of what preceded and will come.

The Fourth: Ibn Abd al-Barr said in "Al-Tamhid" (6 / 364) - having mentioned that the woman is all 'Awrah except the face and hands and that it is the saying of the Imams and their companions and the saying of Al-Awza'i and Abu Thawr -: [30]

Abu Bakr bin Abdur-Rahman bin Al-Harith said: Everything of the woman even her fingernail." text: First: The Madhhab of Abu Hanifa: Imam Muhammad bin Al-Hasan said in "Al-Muwatta" (p. 205 with the commentary Al-Ta'liq Al-Mumajjad - Indian ed.): It is not appropriate for a woman in Ihram (Muhrima) to wear a Niqab (face veil). If she wants to cover her face, she should let down the garment (Sadl) from above her head cover (Khimar). This is the saying of Abu Hanifa and the generality of our jurists. And Abu Ja'far At-Tahawi said in "Sharh Al-Ma'ani" (2 / 392 - 393): It was permitted for people to look at what is not prohibited for them of women, at their faces and hands, and that was forbidden for them regarding the wives of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. This is the saying of Abu Hanifa, Abu Yusuf, and Muhammad, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on them. Second: The Madhhab of Malik: His companion Abdur-Rahman Ibn Al-Qasim Al-Misri narrated from him in "Al-Mudawwanah" (2 / 221) similar to the saying of Imam Muhammad regarding the Muhrima if she wants to let down [a cloth] over her face, and he added in clarification saying: But if she does not want to cover, she does not let it down. Ibn Abd al-Barr quoted it in "Al-Tamhid" (15 / 111) and approved of it, and said after mentioning the interpretation of Ibn Abbas and Ibn Umar for the verse: (except what appears thereof) [34]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: as the face and hands (6 / 369): And upon the saying of Ibn Abbas and Ibn Umar are the jurists in this chapter. (He said:) This is what came regarding the woman and her ruling in covering in her prayer and other than her prayer. Reflect on his saying: "and other than her prayer". And in "Al-Muwatta", the narration of Yahya (2 / 935): Malik was asked: Does a woman eat with other than her Mahrams or with her servant boy? Malik said: There is no harm in that if it is in a manner in which it is known for a woman to eat with men. He said: And a woman may eat with her husband and with others who eat with him. Al-Baji said in "Al-Muntaqa Sharh Al-Muwatta" (7 / 252) following this text: It implies that a man looking at a woman's face and hands is permissible because that appears from her when she is eating. Third: The Madhhab of Shafi'i: He said in his book "Al-Umm" (2 / 185): The Muhrima does not cover (Tukhammir) her face unless she wants to cover her face, then she keeps it away [from the skin]. Al-Baghawi said in "Sharh As-Sunnah" (9 / 23): If she is a free foreign woman (Ajnabiyyah), then her entire body is 'awrah regarding a man; it is not permissible [35] for him to look at anything of it except the face and the hands up to the wrists, and he must lower his gaze from looking at her face and hands as well when there is fear of Fitnah (temptation). So are these texts - O Sheikh - regarding prayer? Fourth: The Madhhab of Ahmed: Ibn Salih narrated in his "Masa'il" (1 / 319) from him that he said: The Muhrima does not cover (Tukhammir) her face nor wear a Niqab, and letting down (Sadl) has no harm in it; she lets down [a cloth] over her face. I say: So his saying: "has no harm in it" indicates the permissibility of letting down (Sadl), so the Sheikh's claim of its obligation is invalidated, just as his restriction of the other narration from the Imam - which agrees with the saying of the three Imams that her face and hands are not 'awrah - is invalidated, as previously mentioned in the words of Ibn Hubayra. Ibn Taymiyyah affirmed it in "Al-Fatawa" (15 / 371), and it is the correct view of his Madhhab as previously mentioned from "Al-Insaf", and it is the choice of Ibn Qudamah as previously mentioned in "The First Research". He justified that by saying: If the face and hands were 'awrah, covering them with Niqab would not be forbidden [in Ihram], because the need calls for uncovering the face for selling and buying, and the hands for taking and giving. Such reasoning was mentioned in many Fiqh books and others, such as "Al-Bahr Ar-Ra'iq" by Ibn Nujaym Al-Misri (1 / 284), and similar was mentioned from Ash-Shawkani at the beginning of this "Fifth Research" (27) [36]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: From the foregoing, it becomes clear to the noble readers that the sayings of the four Imams agree on giving the woman in Ihram the choice to let down [a cloth] over her face and not obligating that upon her, contrary to the strict ones and the blind followers. This is from one angle. From another angle, the saying of Malik in "Al-Muwatta" and the saying of Ibn Abd al-Barr: "and other than her prayer" indicate the invalidity of the mentioned interpretation of At-Tuwaijri, as well as the Imams giving the choice to the Muhrimas regarding Sadl (letting down the cloth), because that is outside of prayer. I want now to clarify to our virtuous readers a knowledge that those mentioned have concealed - or were ignorant of, and the sweeter of the two is bitter - that the predecessor (Salaf) of the Imams, may Allah have mercy on them - in what preceded - is the Mother of the Believers, Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, in word and deed. As for the word: It is: (Authentic/Sahih) "The Muhrima may wear whatever she wishes of clothes except a garment touched by Wars or Saffron, and she does not wear a Burqa' nor a Litham (face veil), and she lets down the garment over her face if she wishes" (1). Al-Bayhaqi reported it in his "Sunan" (5 / 47) with an authentic chain, and Al-Hafiz attributed it to him
foot_note:
1. (1) The Sheikh turned away from mentioning this Athar (narration) because it is a proof against him. And when the author of what he called "Fasl Al-Khitab" (p. 45) mentioned it from this narration of Al-Bayhaqi, he omitted from it the point of evidence against them as well: "if she wishes", because it implies non-obligation. Out of his ignorance, he thinks that the Athar without this addition implies obligation, while it only implies permissibility, and the addition confirms it. Regrettably, brother Al-Iskandarani imitated him in this omission (3 / 304), even though he attributed it to Al-Bayhaqi by volume and page. Has blind following reached this limit, or is it participation in the sin of omission and concealing the truth? 
[37].

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: in "Al-Fath" (4 / 52 - 53) remaining silent about it [implying acceptance], so it is established according to him. It is a strong witness for her previous hadith in this "Fifth Research" page (27 - 28): "O Asma, if a woman reaches menstruation..." Likewise, her following hadith testifies to it. As for the deed, it is what came in the hadith of her Umrah from At-Tan'im with her brother Abdur-Rahman. She said: (Authentic/Sahih) "So he let me ride behind him on a camel of his. She said: So I began lifting my Khimar (head cover), exposing my neck, so he would strike my leg with the side of the mount (1). I said to him: Do you see anyone?..." Muslim reported it (4 / 34) and An-Nasa'i in "As-Sunan Al-Kubra" (2 / 223 - Photostat) and Al-Tayalisi also in his "Musnad" (1561) but with the wording: "So I began uncovering my Khimar so he handed me something from his hand" and from it fell her saying: "my neck". And the narration of Muslim is more authentic in chain and weightier in text as I explained in "The Introduction". Therefore, the Sheikh did not attribute it to Muslim, and some of the blind followers followed him in that - like the one called Darwish in his "Fasl" (p. 43) - because it is a proof against them from the perspective that the Khimar does not cover the face linguistically as previously mentioned, and her being a Mu'tamirah (performing Umrah)

[38].

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: so it is not permissible for her to veil her face with it (Talaththum) as she said just now. So her covering of her face by letting down the cloth (Sadl) - as in some narrations - is an action from her which we acknowledge, but it does not indicate obligation, contrary to the claim of the opponents. I say: By this explanation, the interpretation of the mentioned Sheikh is invalidated due to its contradiction of the sayings of the Imams of Fiqh which explicitly state the permissibility of uncovering the face in prayer and outside it in the presence of men, and due to some of them reasoning the permissibility by the woman's need to buy and sell and take and give, and by the permissibility of eating together as well. The Sheikh interprets all these sayings to be regarding prayer and not in the presence of men, so what a false interpretation, nay, negation (Ta'til). Indeed we belong to Allah and indeed to Him we return. Furthermore, what confirms the Sheikh's ignorance of Fiqh and the sayings of the jurists - or at least his feigning ignorance, prejudice against me, and arrogance against the truth - is that among the references of his book (p. 109) is Ibn Muflih in "Al-Adab Al-Shar'iyyah". Ibn Muflih is one of the great Hanbali scholars of the eighth century and one of Ibn Taymiyyah's students. He used to say to him: "You are not Ibn Muflih, rather you are Muflih (Successful)." Ibn al-Qayyim said about him: There is no one under the dome of the sky more knowledgeable of the Madhhab of Imam Ahmed than Ibn Muflih (1). If you know this, then this Muflih said in his mentioned book "Al-Adab Al-Shar'iyyah" (1 / 316) the following text:

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: "Is it permissible to rebuke foreign women if they uncover their faces in the road? [The answer] relies on whether it is obligatory for the woman to cover her face or obligatory to lower the gaze from her? There are two opinions on the issue. Qadi Iyad said regarding the hadith of Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I asked the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, about the sudden glance? So he ordered me to divert my gaze. Narrated by Muslim. The scholars, may Allah have mercy on them, said: And in this is a proof that it is not obligatory for the woman to cover her face in her path, but rather that is a Sunnah and recommended for her (1), and it is obligatory for the man to lower his gaze from her in all situations except for a legitimate purpose. Sheikh Muhyi al-Din An-Nawawi mentioned it and did not add to it" meaning: in "Sharh Muslim" before (The Book of Peace) and he approved it. Then Al-Muflih mentioned the saying of Ibn Taymiyyah which At-Tuwaijri relies upon in his book (p. 170), and ignored the sayings of the majority of scholars and the saying of Qadi Iyad which Al-Muflih quoted and approved following An-Nawawi. Then Al-Muflih said: Based on this, is rebuke (Inkar) prescribed? It relies on [the principle of] rebuke in issues of dispute, and discussion on it has preceded. But as for our saying and the saying of a group of the Shafi'is and others: That looking at a foreign woman is permissible without desire or seclusion. Then rebuke is not appropriate.
foot_note:
1. (1) Let the noble reader reflect on this saying of the scholars to know that it is our saying, and that the slander At-Tuwaijri directed at us applies to them as well. Ash-Shawkani quoted it and approved it as previously mentioned (p. 27) 
[40].

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: I said: This is what this Hanbali Imam said six centuries ago (d. 763) following those whom I followed from the previous Imams. Does the Sheikh and those who were misled by him - may Allah guide them - not know that the slander he directed at me at the end of his book - as previously mentioned - which is his saying: And whoever permits the unveiling of women and uses as evidence for that the likes of what Al-Albani used as evidence has opened the door of Tabarruj (display of beauty) wide open to the end of his nonsense, may Allah guide him, applies to them (the Imams) may Allah have mercy on them? The Sixth Research: Their negation (Ta'til) of the authentic hadiths that contradict them. Many hadiths have come regarding women uncovering their faces and hands - as will come in the book - the sum of which reaches the level of moral mass transmission (Tawatur Ma'nawi) among the people of knowledge. Therefore, the majority of scholars acted upon them. But the fanatical blind followers have also directed the pickaxes of sabotage and destruction at them by interpreting them, negating them, and invalidating their meanings and clear apparent indications, just as they did with the sayings of the Imams as you knew just now. There is no room here to debate them in all their interpretations, for their abundance requires composing a special treatise listing the hadiths and their sayings in interpreting them and then refuting them. So at least mentioning some models of them will suffice the fair reader regarding the rest. The First Hadith: It is the second in the book (p. 61 - 62), the hadith of the Khath'amiyyah woman, and in it is that she was beautiful and radiant, and in it: "So Al-Fadl began looking at her and her beauty impressed him." [41]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: So I say: The Sheikh and his imitators or agreers were inconsistent in separating themselves from the explicit indication of the hadith in several ways: Sometimes he says (p. 208): There is nothing in it that the woman was uncovering her face, so it is possible that Ibn Abbas meant the beauty of her stature and figure and the radiance of what appeared of her extremities (Atraf). This is speech whose beginning contradicts its end and its end contradicts its beginning, for her "extremities" are the hands, feet, and head - as is known in the language - and accordingly what he denied in the beginning he affirmed in the end, but by way of twisting and turning - regrettably - for "her extremities" include the face linguistically. In "Al-Qamus": The Atraf (extremities) of the body: The hands, legs, and head. Was the Sheikh ignorant of this linguistic fact - as is his habit in his interpretation of (Jilbab), (Khimar), and (I'tijar) - or did he forget it for deception and misleading? If it was the first, was he ignorant of his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Authentic/Sahih) "When the servant prostrates, seven extremities (Atraf) prostrate with him: his face and his hands..." The Hadith (1), or did he forget it too? Whether it was this or that, the sweeter of them is bitter. And soon (p. 44) will come what indicates that he did that for deception, for there it is: "the extremities of her hands"

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: And sometimes he says (p. 219): "And even if Al-Fadl had seen her face, his seeing does not indicate that she was persisting..." And this is another stubbornness resembling the previous one in terms of ignoring facts, for the saying of Ibn Abbas: So Al-Fadl began looking (turning to look) at her, and in the other narration: "So he began (Tafiq) looking at her and her beauty impressed him" invalidates the saying of the Sheikh and those who imitated him like our good brother Muhammad bin Ismail (3 / 368) - and that is from two angles: First: His saying: "Looking (turning to look)" implies the continuation of the action as is known. Second: His saying: "Fa-Tafiq" (So he began/continued), for its meaning is: He continued looking, like His saying, Exalted is He: (So he began [Tafiq] stroking [with his sword] the legs and necks) [Sad: 33] and His saying: (And they began [Tafiqa] sticking upon themselves from the leaves of Paradise) [Al-A'raf: 22]. And similar to it in Al-Bukhari in the story of Moses, peace be upon him, bathing alone: "So he began [Tafiq] striking the stone" and in it also in the hadith of the Hijrah: "So Abu Bakr began [Tafiq] worshipping his Lord." Therefore, Ibn Battal said - as will come in the book (p. 63) -: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, did not turn Al-Fadl's face away until he persisted in looking at her due to his admiration of her, etc. Then he used that as evidence that a woman covering her face is not obligatory. This is what [43]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: cannot be understood otherwise by scholars who are free from sectarian fanaticism. Therefore, Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar - with his vast knowledge and knowledge of language and its etiquette - could not but say in response to Ibn Battal: She was a Muhrima (in Ihram), as will come there. And it is not hidden from the people of knowledge that this answer is only valid if it were not permissible for the Muhrima to cover her face by letting down [a cloth] over it, and this is something neither Al-Hafiz nor others among the scholars say; it is rejected. Some of them might feel the weakness of this response, so they deviate from the clear indication of the hadith on the permissibility of uncovering her face to saying that there is no proof in it for the permissibility of looking at her face, as came in the treatise of Sheikh Ibn Uthaymeen and others. So we say: Yes, that is not permissible when there is fear of Fitnah, and for that reason, it is not permissible for her to look at the face of a foreign man during Fitnah. So is it obligatory for him to cover it from her? The Second Hadith: It is the third in the book (p. 64 - 65), the hadith of the woman who said: "O Messenger of Allah, I came to gift myself to you..." the Hadith. I say: It is ironically tragic that Sheikh At-Tuwaijri crammed this hadith into the group of hadiths he used to prove that it is permissible for a suitor to look at the face of his fiancee and her neck (sic) and the extremities of her hands (1). And when he answered (p. 219) regarding

text: my using the hadith as evidence, he gave the impression that it is regarding a betrothed woman, while he knows that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, had not proposed to her - as I mentioned there from Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar - but rather she offered herself to him, peace and blessings be upon him, as is explicit in the hadith. This was in the mosque as in the narration of Al-Isma'ili and in full view of Sahl bin Sa'd, its narrator, and the people he was among, as in a narration of Al-Bukhari, Abu Ya'la, and At-Tabarani, and their narration is more complete as I listed there. So did it settle in the mind of the Sheikh and his imitators that proposing in full view of strangers is permissible? This is the matter they deny and exaggerate in denying, even by distorting words from their places, like the saying of some of them: Is it not in the hadith that she was uncovering her face? mentioned by the brother in "Al-Awda" (3 / 368) along with other sayings not worth mentioning due to the clarity of their falseness, among them the mentioned saying of At-Tuwaijri, and among them: That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, is infallible (Ma'sum). This is a word of truth intended for falsehood because the discussion is about the vision of the Sahaba (Companions) as is not hidden to anyone with eyes. In my opinion, the virtuous Sheikh Muhammad bin Salih bin Uthaymeen only did not address the answer to the hadith with any of these answers due to the appearance of their weakness, so he saw safety in silence and leaving argumentation, may Allah reward him with good. Although I hope from him to reconsider the issue in light of the clarification that preceded and what will come in [45]

text: the book of new benefits and additions that were not in previous editions. The Third Hadith: It is the fifth in the book (p. 66), which is the hadith of Fatima bint Qais and his command, peace and blessings be upon him, to her to move to Ibn Umm Maktum the blind man, and he said to her: "For if you put down your Khimar (head cover), he will not see you." I explained there the aspect of the hadith's indication that the face is not 'awrah. The Sheikh rejected that (p. 221 - 223) after long speech with no benefit, inserting into it what I do not say. Among that is his saying: And where is the text in the hadith regarding the obligation of covering the head alone and the prohibition of uncovering it before foreign men without the face and neck? I say: As for the text, it is in his permission for her to appear before the guests with her Khimar which does not cover the face, were it not for the fear of it falling off her so they would see her head. Therefore, he commanded her to move to Ibn Umm Maktum, may Allah be pleased with him, and he, peace and blessings be upon him, justified that by saying: "For if you put down your Khimar, he will not see you." And the Khimar is the head cover according to the masses of scholars as previously verified in a way that cannot be rejected by anyone who understands and is fair. So this is the text regarding the head without the face. As for your saying: "and the neck", it is a cheap insertion. I do not know if the like of it can come from a virtuous, pious Sheikh who knows what comes out of his mouth? For he knows that mentioning the neck is not the subject of research and that there is no disagreement regarding it being 'awrah and that the Khimar covers it. So I seek refuge in Allah from decrease after increase (Al-Hawr ba'd Al-Kawr). As for your objection to my mentioned deduction by your saying (p. 222): [46]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: "And if the matter were so, he, peace and blessings be upon him, would have said: For if you put down your Khimar, he will not see your head or he will not see your hair." I say: Enough, O Sheikh, of argumentation and obstinacy, for the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, does not speak according to your whim. He is the most eloquent who spoke Arabic (Dad) and was given comprehensive words. For (Khimar) has a meaning in the language that Fatima, may Allah be pleased with her, understood, contrary to your unintelligible understanding, so there was no need for him to tell her what you proposed and obligated us with. Do you not see that the least understanding person can turn it against you and say to you: "And if the matter were as you claim, that the Khimar covers the face also linguistically, he would have said: For if you put down your Khimar, he will not see your head and your face." So will you commit to this, O poor Sheikh, or will you answer similarly to my mentioned answer that the Khimar allegedly includes the face as well? Then it becomes clear to you that what you obligated us with is not binding and that you argue with falsehood to mislead people without knowledge. For in all your book and your response, you did not bring a text from the Book and Sunnah and the sayings of the early Imams - despite their different specializations - witnessing to your mentioned claim, and you will absolutely never find a way to that. Evidence of this is the clear statement of your countryman, the virtuous Sheikh Muhammad bin Uthaymeen: That the Khimar is what a woman covers her head with - as previously quoted from him. Therefore - I think - he also saw safety in not involving himself in the likes of your argumentation and obstinacy, so he did not address answering our deduction from this hadith. That is only due to the strength of its indication, and praise be to Allah by whose grace good deeds are completed. [47]

text:
The Seventh Research: Their deduction using weak Hadiths and flimsy Athars (narrations) and their persistence on that after they stood upon their defects which prevent them legally (Shar'an) from using them as evidence if they were fair and did not follow their desires. Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in "Al-Fatawa" (1 / 246): And what is transmitted from the Salaf and the scholars requires knowledge of the establishment of its wording and knowledge of its indication, just as what is transmitted from Allah and His Messenger requires that. The Sheikh seems ignorant of this saying of Ibn Taymiyyah, for he did not verify what was transmitted from the Salaf nor its indication; rather, some of it is proof against him. Here are some examples: The First Hadith: From Ibn Abbas who said: (Weak) "Allah commanded the believing women, if they go out of their houses for a need, to cover their faces... and show one eye." It will come in the book (p. 88). I clarified there that the hadith has two defects, so they closed their eyes to them and all followed in using it as evidence. As-Sindi declared (p. 19 - 20) the authenticity of its chain without verifying that according to the method of the scholars of Hadith - may Allah treat him as he deserves - and that was hidden from Al-Iskandarani so he approved it (2 / 265), and Allah's help is sought. Sheikh At-Tuwaijri repeated it repeatedly (p. 163, 226, and 265) and attributed me, because of my opposition to him, to heresy (Ilhad), so he said (p. 233): [48]

"And Al-Albani's speech in interpreting the Verse of Ahzab has not been preceded by anyone from the Sahaba and the Tabi'in, and he has contradicted what came from the Ink of the Ummah (Ibn Abbas) and others from the great Tabi'in in interpreting it. So it is, therefore, from heresy (Ilhad) regarding the verses of Allah Almighty and distortion of words..." Thus he said - may Allah guide him - and I will not counter him except with His saying, Exalted is He, teaching us: (And indeed, we or you are either upon guidance or in clear error) [Saba: 24]. But I will prove to every fair person that the Sheikh's words will rebound on him, fulfilling his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, in the hadith agreed upon as authentic: (Authentic/Sahih) "And whoever calls a man with disbelief or says: Enemy of Allah, and he is not so, except that it returns upon him" and the saying of the proverb: "She accused me of her disease and slipped away." That is because there is another narration from Ibn Abbas - in the source from which the Sheikh quoted the first narration, which is "Al-Durr Al-Manthur" - which the Sheikh and his imitators concealed because it contradicts their desires. Its text regarding the interpretation of the verse of Idna (lowering) is: "And the lowering (Idna) of the Jilbab is that she puts it on her head (Tuqanni') and tightens it on her forehead." Narrated by Ibn Jarir and Ibn Mardawayh. This is the text of our saying, and Ibn Jarir mentioned it (22 / 33) under his saying: And others said: Rather, they were commanded to tighten their Jilbabs on their foreheads. This, although its chain is weak, is weightier than the first for several reasons:

text:
1 - That it is closer to the word (Al-Idna - Lowering) as previously mentioned in "The First Research" [49]

2 - That it agrees with what is authentically reported from Ibn Abbas via seven paths from him: That the face and hands are from the apparent adornment which is permissible to uncover. I extracted the seven paths in "The Introduction" and some of them are authentic - as will come in the book - and it is explicit in the intent as Ibn Al-Qattan Al-Fasi said in "An-Nazar fi Ahkam An-Nazar" (p. 20 / 2) and he strengthened it by confirming the trustworthiness of its narrators. As-Sindi pointed to its chains asserting their lack of authenticity (p. 18). It is from his malice and deception that he listed the weak ones among them and elaborated on their defects while concealing the authentic ones among them. Al-Iskandarani approved him (3 / 265) due to his ignorance of this noble science. Therefore, he has wronged himself and his readers by entering into what he does not master.

Narrated by Abu Dawud in his "Masa'il" (p. 110) with a very authentic chain (1)

1. (1) I say: His name is Jabir bin Zaid Al-Basri, a majestic trustworthy Tabi'i. Adh-Dhahabi said in "Al-Siyar" (4 / 482): And he is among the senior students of Ibn Abbas. I say: And it is authentically reported from Ibn Abbas that he said: "If the people of Basra had settled on the saying of Jabir bin Zaid, he would have sufficed them in knowledge regarding the Book of Allah." Abu Nu'aym reported it (3 / 85) and others with an authentic chain from him. And he narrated (3 / 89) with a good chain from Hind bint Al-Muhallab who said: "Jabir bin Zaid was the most devoted person to me and to my mother... and he used to command me to place the Khimar. text: 4 - That it is what is reported from some students of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, like Sa'id bin Jubayr, for he interpreted Idna (lowering): as placing the Qina' (veil) over the Khimar (head cover). And he said: It is not permissible for a Muslim woman to be seen by a stranger unless she has the Qina' over the Khimar and has tightened it over her head and throat. This will come in the book (p. 85). And Abu Bakr Al-Jassas mentioned similarly in "Ahkam Al-Qur'an" (3 / 372) from Mujahid as well, coupled with Ibn Abbas: The free woman covers her forehead and head when she goes out. And Mujahid is among those who received the interpretation of the Quran from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them. Then Qatada, may Allah have mercy on them, received it from Mujahid, for he is among his students and narrators from him. So he said regarding the interpretation of (Idna): Allah took a covenant from them that if they go out they should wear the Qina' (Taqannu') on the eyebrows.

This is a Shadh (anomalous) addition that is not authentic because Yahya is a mountain in memorization. Ahmed said: "He is the ultimate in precision in Basra." And he said: "He is more precise than these." Meaning: Ibn Mahdi and others. If you compare this testimony from him with his saying about Ruh: "There was no harm in him," you know the difference between them and do not accept his addition over Yahya. [51].

text: Narrated by Ibn Jarir (22 / 23) with an authentic chain from him (1). So his saying: "Yuqanni'na" means: they wear the Qina' and tighten it on the eyebrows and head, for (Al-Qina') is wider than Al-Miqna', and Al-Miqna' is what a woman covers her head with as in "Al-Qamus" and others, and similar preceded (p. 19 - 20) from Al-Hafiz and others. So it is truly strange and odd that Sheikh At-Tuwaijri - and those who imitated him from the gatherers and collectors - mentions this Athar after this weak hadith of Ibn Abbas and following that the Athar of 'Abida Al-Salmani - the defects of which will be explained. He mentioned this Athar after that citing it as evidence, while it is proof against him as you see. I do not know - by Allah - is this from the Sheikh's ignorance of his language or intentional ignoring from him? If it is the first, was it hidden from him that Imam Ibn Jarir mentioned it as a heading for the second opinion opposing the saying of those who held the weak hadith of Ibn Abbas? For he said after it (22 / 33): And others said: Rather, they were commanded to tighten their Jilbabs on their foreheads. He mentioned who said that? Then he cited under it the hadith of Ibn Abbas which is in the process of being preferred by these four matters, following it with this Athar of Qatada. Do I not have the right, after this clarification, to say: That what the Sheikh accused me of

text: contradicting the Sahaba and Tabi'in and heresy (Ilhad) regarding the verses of Allah Almighty and distorting words... that it describes him? And that what he attributed to Ibn Abbas assertively is a lie upon him? And that I am the happiest of people to follow him, may Allah be pleased with him, in the preferred narration from him regarding the interpretation of the noble verse and in others as will come in the interpretation of: (except what appears thereof) (p. 102). And if the weakness of Ibn Abbas's hadith commanding women to cover their faces except one eye becomes clear, and that the other narration from him explicitly stating tightening the Jilbab on her forehead is stronger than it - due to its witnesses and its agreement with (Idna) linguistically and regarding its interpretation - a bitter regrettable truth becomes clear to the noble readers: That Sheikh At-Tuwaijri has established a bad sunnah (precedent) for those who wrote on this issue, which is using as evidence what is not authentic of hadiths despite his knowledge of their weakness and their defect explained in my book - as will come (p. 73) - and his turning away from answering it and from mentioning what contradicts it. So upon him applies his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, which he places at the end of his book (p. 249) out of place, thus wronging me with it - which is his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "...And whoever establishes in Islam a bad sunnah, upon him is its burden and the burden of those who act upon it until the Day of Resurrection..." the Hadith. For the generality of those who agreed with him imitated him in using this flimsy hadith as evidence and remaining silent about it. Among them is one whose use of it in "Risalat Al-Hijab" (p. 12) was hard on me, because I thought he investigates the authentic Sunnah, especially in what he knows scholars have differed over. So how [53]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text:
is the condition of the others who are good at nothing but blind following and clamor? Indeed, some of them exceeded them and took a stance on what he has no knowledge of, so he authenticated it, namely the one called Salih bin Ibrahim Al-Baleeh in what he called "O Girl of Islam" (p. 201 and 252). This is something no scholar has said before and cannot be uttered by a beginner in this science. For here is the author of the book "Al-Hijab", brother Mustafa Al-Adawi, one of the emerging ones in this field, he had no choice but to admit the weakness of its chain (p. 28 and 46), although he concealed the second defect in it which is the weakness of Abdullah bin Salih as previously mentioned, but he declared it in his other book "Ahkam An-Nisa" (p. 19). What draws attention and catches the eye is the saying of the virtuous Sheikh Ibn Uthaymeen after quoting the hadith assertively: And the interpretation of the Sahabi is proof, rather some scholars said: It is in the ruling of Marfu' (raised) to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. So I say: Yes, but establish the throne then engrave (establish the basis before the details). It was obligatory upon you, O virtuous Sheikh, before saying this, to answer the two defects of the hadith and prove its authenticity according to the principles of the science of Hadith as is supposed in such issues of dispute, especially while you are in the process of refuting your opponent who has weakened your hadith before. So if you accept its weakness, why did you use it as evidence? And if you see its authenticity, why did you not respond to him and establish the proof of its authenticity? Is this not incompatible [54]

with the good word you mentioned in your treatise, wherein it came (p. 32): That it is obligatory upon every researcher seeking justice and fairness... to stand between the evidences of the dispute in the position of a judge between two adversaries, so he judges by way of knowledge and does not prefer one of the two sides without a preponderant reason? I do not think you did what you obligated, because if you had done so, you would not have used it as evidence - Allah willing - due to the clarity of its weakness. Or if it is the opposite and you saw its authenticity - and this is very far from "every researcher" - then why did you conceal the proof of its authenticity? Is this the position of a judge between two adversaries? (O you who have believed, why do you say what you do not do. Great is hatred in the sight of Allah that you say what you do not do) [As-Saff: 2 & 3]. The Second Hadith: From the weak [narrations] which they used as evidence and which Sheikh At-Tuwaijri and his imitators were fond of: (Weak) "Ibn Sirin's asking 'Abida Al-Salmani regarding the verse of (Idna)? So 'Abida veiled himself with a large sheet (Milhaf) and covered his entire head until he reached the eyebrows and covered his face and brought out his left eye." As-Suyuti extracted it in "Al-Durr" (5 / 221) and At-Tuwaijri quoted it (p. 163 - 164). And the clarification of its weakness is from several aspects:

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text:
1 - That it is Maqtu' (severed) Mawquf (stopped at a Tabi'i), so there is no proof in it because 'Abida Al-Salmani is a Tabi'i by agreement. So if he had raised a hadith to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, it would be Mursal (hurried) in which there is no proof, so how about when it is stopped at him like this? Especially when he contradicted the interpretation of the Translator [55]

of the Quran: Ibn Abbas and those with him from the Sahaba?

2 - That they were inconsistent (Idtirab) in specifying the exposed eye in it. So it was said: "The left" - as you saw - and it was said: "The right" which is the narration of At-Tabari (22 / 33), and it was said: "One of his eyes" which is another narration of his, and similar to it is in "Ahkam Al-Qur'an" by Al-Jassas (3 / 371) and "Tafsir Al-Baghawi" (3 / 444) and others.

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text:
3 - Ibn Taymiyyah mentioned it in "Al-Fatwa" (15 / 371) with another context completely different from the mentioned context, for he said: And 'Abida Al-Salmani and others mentioned: That the women of the believers used to lower the Jilbabs over themselves from above their heads so that nothing appears but their eyes for the sake of seeing the road. At-Tuwaijri quoted it from him (166) and Ibn Uthaymeen (p. 13) and others and approved it. If you know this, then know that Idtirab (disturbance/inconsistency) according to the scholars of Hadith is a defect in the narration that drops it from the rank of being used as evidence, even if it was formal like this, because it indicates that the narrator did not precise it nor memorize it. However, the mentioned context of Ibn Taymiyyah is not formal as is apparent, because it is not in the interpretation of the verse, but rather it is information about the reality of women in the first era. And in this meaning, it is authentic and established in many reports as will come in the book under the title: "The Legitimacy of Covering the Face" (p. 104). But that does not imply the obligation of covering because it is merely an action from them, and it does not negate the existence of those who did not cover their faces. Rather, this is also established in [56]

his time, peace and blessings be upon him, as will come and as some of it has preceded.

text: 4 - Its contradiction to Ibn Abbas's interpretation of the verse as previously explained, so what contradicts him is discarded without doubt. The Third Hadith: From Muhammad bin Ka'b Al-Qurazi like the first hadith of Ibn Abbas regarding: (they should bring down over themselves from their outer garments). He said: (Fabricated/Mawdu') "She covers her face except one of her eyes." Ibn Sa'd reported it in "Al-Tabaqat" (8 / 176 - 177): Muhammad bin Umar informed us from Ibn Abi Sabra from Abu Sakhr from him. I say: And this is a fabricated chain whose bane is Ibn Abi Sabra. Imam Ahmed said in "Al-Ilal" (1 / 204): He used to lie and fabricate hadith. And the narrator from him Muhammad bin Umar - who is Al-Waqidi - is close to him. Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Taqrib": Matruk (Abandoned). And Ahmed said: "Liar". Then in addition to that, it is Mursal (hurried) as will come in the book (p. 90 - 91). Despite this calamity in the chain of this hadith, brother Muhammad bin Ismail mentioned it in "Al-Awda" (3 / 214) remaining silent about it while attributing it to "Al-Tabaqat" [57]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text:
just as Sheikh At-Tuwaijri remained silent about it in more than one place in his book (p. 227 and 233), indicating thereby the strengthening of the first hadith. Beginners in this science know that such a ruined chain is not suitable for strengthening. But are they knowledgeable of it or are they wood-gathering transmitters? The sweeter of the two is bitter. The Fourth Hadith: From Al-Fadl bin Abbas who said: (Weak) I was riding behind the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and a Bedouin was with a daughter of his, beautiful. So he began offering her to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, hoping he would marry her. He said: So I began turning to look at her and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, began taking my head and twisting it. Abu Ya'la reported it in his "Musnad" (12 / 97) from the path of Yunus bin Abi Ishaq from Abu Ishaq from Sa'id bin Jubayr from Ibn Abbas from him. I say: And this is a weak chain, its narrators are trustworthy but its text is Munkar (denounced). It has five defects: First: The 'an'anah (narrating with 'from') of Abu Ishaq - who is Al-Sabi'i - for he is a Mudallis (obfuscator). Second: His mixing (Ikhtilat), so his hadith is not used as proof except what he narrated before mixing with his declaration of hearing (Tahdith), and that is not available here. As for the first, for what follows, and as for the other, for what preceded. Third: Lenience in his son Yunus, and perhaps that is specific to his narration from his father [58]

for he narrated from him after the mixing, as asserted by Ibn Numayr in what Al-Hafiz Ibn Rajab Al-Hanbali quoted from him in "Sharh Ilal At-Tirmidhi" (2 / 520) and see (2 / 672) of it. Fourth: His contradiction of his son Israel, who is trustworthy and has better memory than his father. For he narrated this hadith from his grandfather with it in chain and text except that he did not mention: "and a Bedouin with a daughter of his... hoping he would marry her". Ahmed reported it (1 / 213) and At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" (18 / 288). I say: And Israel is prioritized in case of difference over Yunus as preceded, and that is why Imam Ahmed said: The hadith of Israel is more beloved to me than him. I say: So this addition is Munkar due to the mentioned contradiction. This is on the assumption that it is not from the confusions of Abu Ishaq and that he did not narrate it. But if he narrated it, it would be Shadh (anomalous) due to what we mentioned of his condition. And for another defect, which is: Fifth: His contradiction of all the trustworthy narrators who narrated the hadith from Ibn Abbas without the addition, and they are four as far as I found, and all are trustworthy:

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text:
1 - Sulayman bin Yasar in the "Two Sahihs" and others, and its referencing will come in the book (p. 61 - 62) [59]

2 - Al-Hakam bin Utaybah, narrated by Ahmed with an authentic chain

3 - Ata bin Abi Rabah, Ahmed also with a good chain
