text: 4 - Mujahid with At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and its chain is good as well. What confirms its anomaly (Shudhudh) is that it did not appear in the hadith of Ali also with At-Tirmidhi and he authenticated it, and its referencing will come there. It is not hidden from one with insight into this noble science that a single defect from these five defects is sufficient to weaken the hadith, so how about when they are combined? So the wonder of all wonders is from Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar, how he said in "Al-Fath" (4 / 67): Abu Ya'la narrated it with a strong chain? Sheikh Abdul-Qadir bin Habib Al-Sindi found this strengthening in his treatise "Al-Hijab" so he clung to it and dedicated a research from page (27 - 43 / 5th Edition) in which he tried to prove the authenticity of this chain via twisted strange ways and weak language, much of which is unintelligible due to his foreignness. And what was intelligible from it is what he mostly quoted from others, and in it is what is proof against him invalidating his mentioned authentication, along with a strange contradiction. For he quoted from Al-Hafiz that he said regarding Abu Ishaq Al-Sabi'i: "He mixed up at the end" then he commented saying: [60]

book_title: Ar-Radd al-Mufhim 'ala man Khalafa al-'Ulama wa Tashaddada wa Ta'assaba wa Alzama al-Mar'ah an Tastura Wajhaha wa Kaffayha wa Awjaba wa lam Yaqna' bi-Qawlihim: Innahu Sunnah wa Mustahabbah
text: "I said: The narration of his son Yunus was not during the state of *Ikhtilat* (confusion/memory loss), if Allah the Exalted wills." This—as is apparent—means that he acknowledges *Ikhtilat* as a principle, but he soon recoils from that, saying a few lines later: "And I did not find [evidence of] the *Ikhtilat* of Abu Ishaq, even though Ibn Al-Kayyal mentioned him in his book 'Al-Kawakib Al-Nayyirat' (pp. 341-356)." Thus spoke the poor man! So reconcile, O noble reader—if you can—between his denial of finding [evidence] and his admission that Al-Kayyal mentioned him in the aforementioned book, the full title of which is "Fi Ma'rifat Man Ikhtalata Min Ar-Ruwwat Ath-Thiqat" (On Knowing the Trustworthy Narrators Who Became Confused), and with the testimony of Al-Hafiz [Ibn Hajar] regarding his *Ikhtilat* as well. Others have also mentioned him, such as Ibn As-Salah, Ibn Kathir, and many others. They clarified—may Allah have mercy on them—who narrated from him before the *Ikhtilat*, so he is used as proof, and who narrated from him after it, so he is not used as proof. Among those [who narrated before] is Yunus bin Abi Ishaq, as previously mentioned from Ibn Numayr. This is what Al-Sindi explicitly contradicted just now. How many such contradictions he has! I have counted eight of them from him in this Hadith alone. It would take too long to mention them all, and the place of their clarification is in "Silsilat Al-Ahadith Al-Da'ifah" under number (5959). Among them is his claim that the *Tadlis* (concealing defects) of Abu Ishaq was not harmful, and he rejected Al-Hafiz's listing of him in the third category [of Mudallisin], not knowing the statement of Ibn Al-Qattan in "Al-Wahm wa Al-Iham" (2/208/2): "He used to practice *Tadlis* frequently." [61]

book_title: Ar-Radd al-Mufhim 'ala man Khalafa al-'Ulama wa Tashaddada wa Ta'assaba wa Alzama al-Mar'ah an Tastura Wajhaha wa Kaffayha wa Awjaba wa lam Yaqna' bi-Qawlihim: Innahu Sunnah wa Mustahabbah
text:
Indeed, what drove him to insert himself into what he does not master is merely to appear in the guise of a verifying researcher who brought what the predecessors could not. That is, to present to the hardliners a new weapon to invalidate the indication of the authentic Hadith of the Khath'ami woman regarding the permissibility of uncovering the face. He admitted at the beginning of his research that it contains an approval of uncovering the face, contrary to Sheikh Al-Tuwaijri and his imitators. However, he rationalized her uncovering by saying it was only "for the sake of looking regarding the right of a suitor," as he said (p. 37). He then reiterated this in two other places (p. 38 and 40). It is said to him: You have been afflicted with the mania of interpretation and the nullification of explicit evidences in the authentic Hadith agreed upon [by Bukhari and Muslim], by relying on this denounced addition, even though it does not state that the Prophet (peace be upon him) was a suitor. Rather, it mentions offering herself to him (peace be upon him) so perhaps he might marry her. Even if this were authentic, it is like the Hadith of the woman who offered herself to the Prophet (peace be upon him), which Al-Tuwaijri also interpreted as being for a suitor, yet there was no suitor, as previously explained in the rebuttal to him in "Research Six: Nullifying the Authentic Hadiths Opposing Them" (p. 41), so refer to it for it is important. Furthermore, even if we accepted what Al-Sindi claimed, that does not imply that the story of the Bedouin's daughter is the same as the story of the Khath'ami woman. Rather, this is certainly different from that. Al-Hafiz Ibn Al-Qattan leaned towards this in his book "Al-Nazar fi Ahkam Al-Nazar" (1-2/52) due to the difference in its context from that one, so it remained safe from that destructive interpretation. [62]

The Fifth Hadith: From Umm Salamah who said: I was with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and Maymunah was with him, when Ibn Umm Maktum approached—and that was after we were commanded with the Hijab. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Veil yourselves from him." We said: O Messenger of Allah, is he not blind, unable to see us or recognize us? The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Are you two blind? Do you not see him?" Narrated by the authors of the Sunan except Ibn Majah, and others, via the path of Al-Zuhri: Nabhan, the freed slave of Umm Salamah, told me from her. It is documented in "Al-Irwa" (6 / 210 / 1806) and "Al-Da'ifah" (5958). Whoever wants the details should refer to them, or at least to the first of them because the other has not been printed as of this hour. The summary of the verification contained in them is:

1 - That the Hadith is unique to Nabhan, and [only] Al-Zuhri narrated from him, as stated by Al-Nasa'i, Al-Bayhaqi, Ibn Abd al-Barr, and others.

book_title: Ar-Radd al-Mufhim 'ala man Khalafa al-'Ulama wa Tashaddada wa Ta'assaba wa Alzama al-Mar'ah an Tastura Wajhaha wa Kaffayha wa Awjaba wa lam Yaqna' bi-Qawlihim: Innahu Sunnah wa Mustahabbah
text: 2 - And that Nabhan is *Majhul al-Ayn* (unknown person), as stated by Al-Bayhaqi and Ibn Abd al-Barr. Close to this is the statement of Al-Hafiz [Ibn Hajar] in "At-Taqrib": "Maqbul" (Acceptable) (1), for it means: that he is not accepted...

He did not address strengthening its chain in "Al-Fath" nor rebut it, nor did he answer regarding the narration of Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman also from Nabhan, but in any case, he definitively stated the weakness of this Hadith of his. [63].

book_title: Ar-Radd al-Mufhim 'ala man Khalafa al-'Ulama wa Tashaddada wa Ta'assaba wa Alzama al-Mar'ah an Tastura Wajhaha wa Kaffayha wa Awjaba wa lam Yaqna' bi-Qawlihim: Innahu Sunnah wa Mustahabbah
text: ...except when corroborated, as he stipulated in the introduction of "At-Taqrib". And that his statement in "Al-Fath": "Its chain is strong" is not strong due to its contradiction with his statement in "At-Taqrib" and with the rules of Hadith—as explained in "Al-Da'ifah". Furthermore, his saying: "Maqbul", although supporting the weakness of the Hadith, is not acceptable [itself] because he should have rightfully said in its place: "Majhul" (Unknown), due to the aforementioned isolation of Al-Zuhri in narrating from him. As for what is in his "Tahdhib": that Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman, the freed slave of the family of Talha, also narrated from him, this is not preserved (*Mahfuz*), as verified by Al-Bayhaqi and as I explained there in "Al-Da'ifah". In it is the rebuttal to Al-Hafiz in detail and to others who preceded him or imitated him among the imitators like Al-Tuwaijri and others who opposed scientific verification and the statements of other Imams—among them Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him, as will come. Therefore, Al-Hafiz had no choice but to state explicitly in another place in "Al-Fath" (1 / 550): "It is a Hadith about whose authenticity there is disagreement." Did Sheikh Al-Tuwaijri know of this text from Al-Hafiz or was he ignorant of it? If it is the former, then why did he suffice—whenever he mentioned this Hadith—with mentioning those who authenticated it among the lenient ones, and refuting those who opposed him by saying (p. 154): "And no attention is paid to one who impugns it without relied-upon proof"? Thus he spoke—may Allah guide him—referring thereby to the rebuttal against me, for I had weakened the Hadith due to ignorance [of the narrator] in "Al-Irwa" in the place referred to earlier. Is this how [64]

text: a rebuttal should be, O noble Sheikh? Is this the path of scholars? Do you see that if a refuter responded to your book in which you refute your opponent, or responded to one who imitated you without knowledge or enlightening scripture, and authored his treatise which he named: "Al-Lubab fi Faridat Al-Niqab" (The Core Regarding the Obligation of Niqab) with words like yours, would he be right in his rebuttal or ignorant? Just like that Doctor—they claimed—who authored a book responding to you—or to your imitator referred to—which he named "Tahrim Al-Niqab" (The Prohibition of Niqab)? (1) There is no doubt that he committed an act like yours or similar to it in obstinacy and pretension. I say this although I have not seen his book, but I came across snippets of it refuted in "Majallat Al-Tawhid" published by Jama'at Ansar Al-Sunnah in Cairo / Issue Seven, year (1411). It was incumbent upon you—O noble Sheikh—to advise your readers, recount your opponent's argument, and strike proof with proof as required by the science of Hadith terminology, and not in the manner of imitators whose action is represented by the well-known proverb: "A goat even if it flies." In my opinion, the Sheikh said that feeble word due to his lack of knowledge of those who preceded me in weakening the Hadith and finding a defect in it due to Nabhan. Otherwise, he would not have permitted himself to say it while striking weighty Imams—even to the likes of him among the imitators who have no

And Aisha said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to screen me with his cloak while I looked at the Abyssinians playing in the mosque." Agreed upon [by Bukhari and Muslim]. And because if they were prevented from looking, the Hijab would have been obligatory upon men just as it was made obligatory upon women so they would not look at them. As for the Hadith of Nabhan from Umm Salamah regarding which she said: "I said: ..." then he mentioned the Hadith as previously stated.

text: Then he said:) Ahmad said: Nabhan narrated two strange Hadiths: this Hadith and the other: "If one of you has a *Mukatab* (slave buying his freedom) [who has the money], let her veil herself from him." As if he indicated the weakness of his Hadith since he did not narrate except these two Hadiths that oppose the fundamental principles. Ibn Abd al-Barr said: Nabhan is unknown, not recognized except by Al-Zuhri's narration of this Hadith from him. The Hadith of Fatimah is authentic, so the argument is binding. Furthermore, it is possible that the Hadith of Nabhan is specific to the wives of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). This was the view of Ahmad and Abu Dawood. "The Sheikh mentioned to Ahmad: The Hadith of Nabhan is for his wives (peace be upon him) and the Hadith of Fatimah is for the rest of the people? He said: Yes." The two sons of Qudamah Al-Maqdisi added: Even if a contradiction is assumed, prioritizing authentic Hadiths is better than taking a solitary Hadith whose chain is criticized. What they attributed to Abu Dawood is established in some copies of his "Sunan" as in the copy of "Awn Al-Ma'bud" (4 / 109). Abu Dawood said: This is for the wives of the Prophet (peace be upon him) specifically; do you not see Fatimah bint Qays observing her waiting period at Ibn Umm Maktum's? [67]

text: The summary of the discussion on this Hadith is that the Sheikh and his imitators have contradicted—due to their narrow scientific horizon—Imam Ahmad and his followers among the great Hanbalis and others, both in terms of Hadith and Fiqh. regarding the first, because they authenticated the Hadith while it is weak according to Ahmad and others, flawed by ignorance [of the narrator], a flaw Ibn Al-Qattan did not notice in his "Nazar" (1/66), even though it is his habit to find defects in Hadith due to such things, and even due to the ignorance of the [narrator's] condition (Jahalah Haliyyah), as he did with the Hadith of Umm Subayyah: "My hand and the hand of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) alternated in [taking water for] ablution from one vessel." (Q 20 / 2), which is an authentic Hadith documented in "Sahih Abi Dawood" (71). As for the other [contradiction], it is because they applied it to women in general, while it is specific to his wives (peace be upon him). This is what Al-Hafiz deemed good in "Al-Talkhis" (3 / 148), saying: And Al-Mundhiri combined them [the hadiths] in this way in his margins, and our Sheikh deemed it good. As for non-Hanbalis, Al-Qurtubi said in his "Tafsir" (12 / 228): "This Hadith is not authentic according to the scholars of transmission because its narrator Nabhan is one whose Hadith is not used as proof." So what is the recourse with this Sheikh who takes from statements whatever he desires, even if their error and contradiction to the scholars' rules become clear? (1)

Therefore, he permitted in the end of his book (p. 434) that she uncover her face before a blind man who cannot see her. [68].

book_title: Ar-Radd al-Mufhim 'ala man Khalafa al-'Ulama wa Tashaddada wa Ta'assaba wa Alzama al-Mar'ah an Tastura Wajhaha wa Kaffayha wa Awjaba wa lam Yaqna' bi-Qawlihim: Innahu Sunnah wa Mustahabbah
text: Here, I must draw attention to some deceptions, misleading statements, and obfuscations by Sheikh Abdul Qadir Al-Sindi in his "Hijab", his exploitation of the slips of some scholars, and his turning away from applying their scientific rules which they established for those after them to adhere to and surrender their minds to, not to deviate from them to imitate them in what they contradicted their own rules in, as he did in the biography of Al-Sabi'i and others in the Hadith of the Khath'ami woman (p. 26). So I say: First: He repeated twice on one page (49) his claim that the chain of this Hadith is authentic, then he emphasized that on the page following it, reminding one of the well-known proverb: "A goat even if it flies," because it is a mere claim which he did not substantiate with the biography of its narrator Nabhan at the very least, and what all the Imams of criticism (*Jarh*) said about him, instead of limiting himself to quoting authentication without the declaration of ignorance [of his status]. What follows confirms this. Second: He concealed Al-Hafiz's statement in "At-Taqrib": "Maqbul" (Acceptable), because he knows that he means by it that he is lenient in Hadith, and that it contradicts Al-Hafiz's statement in "Al-Fath" regarding it, which has no basis in science as previously mentioned. Third: He said following his referenced statement in "Al-Fath": And the scholar Al-Mubarakfuri quoted it in Tuhfat Al-Ahwadhi "and supported it." This is a lie against Al-Mubarakfuri because mere quotation does not imply support—as is not hidden from the people of knowledge—especially since he quoted Al-Hafiz's statement in [69]

text: "At-Taqrib"—even if he didn't point to it—: "Nabhan is Maqbul from the third [generation]." He quoted this at the beginning of his explanation of the Hadith, and the statement of "Al-Fath" at its end. If this [latter one] was support, then that [former one] is support too. Al-Mubarakfuri is merely a narrator and was not in the position of researching and verifying to prefer one saying over another, unlike Al-Sindi. Therefore, he concealed the statement of "At-Taqrib" because it necessitates the weakness of the Hadith, due to Al-Sindi's knowledge that it means Nabhan is lenient in Hadith because he has no corroborator. Therefore, he proceeds upon the ominous Jewish principle: "The end justifies the means." Were it not for that, he would have quoted it too and tried to reconcile between them. But since he knew—I think—that criticism (*Jarh*) takes precedence over modification (*Ta'dil*)—especially if the modification needs modification itself—he saw that retreating and fleeing is half of courage—as is said in some lands—so that concealment occurred from him. And Allah is the one whose help is sought. Fourth: Al-Sindi copied Nabhan's biography from the "Tahdhibs" of Al-Mizzi and Al-Asqalani, and in them: that Ibn Hibban mentioned him in "Al-Thiqat", misleading the readers that they authenticated him as well. It is not so, as is known to scholars familiar with their style, which is merely to quote what was said about the subject regarding criticism and modification. That is why Al-Hafiz authored his aforementioned book "Taqrib Al-Tahdhib", for he exercises ijtihad in it, not just copying, presenting his opinion on the subject with the fewest possible words. Researching to verify this is something for which there is no room here. It suffices the intelligent, fair reader as an example of what I mentioned that Al-Hafiz who [70]

text: mentioned in his "Tahdhib" the authentication of Ibn Hibban did not adopt that in his "Taqrib". Rather, he softened him by saying in it: "Maqbul" (Acceptable), meaning: when corroborated, otherwise he is lenient in Hadith when solitary—as is the case here. This is his terminology in it as he stated in his introduction. Fifth: Then Al-Sindi quoted from "Tahdhib Al-Mizzi" the two Hadiths about whose weakness Imam Ahmad expressed wonder—as previously mentioned. One of them is this Hadith: "Are you two blind?" He said following them: "I say: Imam Al-Mizzi sees, may Allah have mercy on him—as you learned from the context of his speech—that these Hadiths (sic) which he narrated in Nabhan's biography are used as proof, and he sees that Nabhan is trustworthy whose Hadith is used as proof, just as he quoted from Al-Nasa'i that he narrated his second Hadith from other paths." I say: This contains four lies against Al-Hafiz Al-Mizzi: The first: That he uses the two mentioned Hadiths as proof—and his saying: "The Hadiths" is from his exaggeration which is hidden from no one—because Al-Hafiz did no more than mention them with their chains to show that he [Nabhan] has no others in the Sunan, and he quoted after them At-Tirmidhi's authentication of them, and to say after them: "So it fell to us as a high substitution (*badalan 'aliyan*)" (1).

Al-Sindi exploited that and attributed to Al-Hafiz that he uses them as proof. His action here is like his action mentioned in (Fourthly), and the rebuttal is the same rebuttal. The Second: That Al-Mizzi sees Nabhan as trustworthy. This is like the one before it, and the rebuttal is the one indicated just now. The Third: His attributing to Al-Mizzi that he said: "He narrated it from other paths." This is a pure lie or malicious deception, for Al-Mizzi only said: "From other paths from Al-Zuhri." I would have liked to say: Perhaps the phrase "from Al-Zuhri" dropped from his pen by mistake, were it not that he repeated that again on the same page, and that there is no benefit in quoting the sentence in full; rather, it is evidence against him because it explicitly indicates Nabhan's isolation with the Hadith. So let the rational person reflect on what desire or ignorance does to its owner and into what deep valley it throws him. We ask Allah for safety. The Fourth: His ignoring his contradiction of the Hadith of Muslim from Fatimah bint Qays as explained by the scholars. Clearer than it is the narration of Al-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" (24 / 377) with an authentic chain from her, she said: "And he (peace be upon him) commanded me to stay at the house of Ibn Umm Maktum, for he is a blind man who cannot see me when I take off my Khimar (headcover)." These are five Hadiths from the weak Hadiths circulated by most authors on the prohibition of [showing] women's faces and hands. They differ in maximizing or minimizing [72]

them according to one's expansion on the subject and what is connected to it. The most expansive of them in this is Sheikh Al-Tuwaijri—may Allah guide him—for he established a bad precedent. He gathered in his book all the flimsy Hadiths he found which he imagines strengthen his argument, not realizing that in reality, they dull his "sword" (*sarim*) and make it blunt and unable to perform what he intended. Their number reached nearly fifty raised (*marfu'*) Hadiths—or more—including the weak, the denounced (*munkar*), and the fabricated (*mawdu'*). It is useful to present to the reader samples of them so they may be aware of them firstly, and so they may know the reality of the Sheikh's knowledge and those who followed his path secondly, without discussing their chains, sufficing with referring to my book in which I documented them and spoke about them in detail.

For the intent is the places of adornment, which are: the earring, the armband, the anklet, and the necklace. This is by agreement of the scholars of Tafsir, and it is narrated from Ibn Mas'ud, and Sheikh Al-Tuwaijri himself mentioned it in his book (p. 156) (1). So this Quranic text is explicit that a woman is not permitted to display before a Muslim woman more than these places. Does the Sheikh believe that among the places of adornment mentioned in the Verse are: her chest, her back, and her waist? By Allah, I am confused by this Sheikh who combines contradictions in his mind. He is strict with women at times, forbidding them what Allah permitted of showing the face and hands, and is lenient with them at times, permitting them what Allah forbade of showing to her Muslim sister what is above her navel. This is a matter which some Hanafis, accused of relying on opinion (*Ra'y*), did not fall into, for they did not hold this view of the Sheikh; they did not permit [showing] the back and belly because they are not places of adornment, as in "Al-Bahr Al-Ra'iq" (8 / 220). What increased my confusion is that by this, he also contradicted the narration of Ibn Mas'ud which the commentators rely upon and which the Sheikh approved (p. 156), because it is in another narration from him that aligns with his aforementioned strictness. Is it ignorance or feigned ignorance and following of desire?

I do not know, by Allah. Brother Al-Adawi imitated him in both matters in his "Hijab" and "Ahkam" (16-17), despite his knowledge—and that of his role model—of the many evils that result from women uncovering themselves before Muslim women, and even before Dhimi women, and even before Mahram men according to the "Madhhab" of Al-Tuwaijri.

text: First: His saying: "with authentic chains." It is false from two aspects: First: That it has only one chain. Second: That this chain itself is not authentic, for Ibn Abd al-Barr and Al-Hafiz found a defect in it due to *Irsal* (disconnection), as mentioned in the book (p. 86), and the Sheikh himself says so. Second: How can it have authentic chains when he says immediately after: "And it is a Mursal Hadith according to the correct view"? These are two contradictory statements that do not come together in the brain of anyone who has smelled even a whiff of the scent of this noble science. The matter is very clear and needs no explanation. Based on the foregoing, do I not have the right to say: So he whose condition is such in ignorance of the science of Hadith and inability to distinguish authentic from weak Hadith—even by way of imitation which is ignorance itself as the knowledgeable say—what business does he have inserting himself into the group of scholars and jurists, and even refuting them and ridiculing their opinions? I do not mean myself—though I hope to be gathered with them—but I mean the majority of scholars from the predecessors and successors whose statements invalidating his own the Sheikh ignored, as previously explained. His condition with them reminded me of the poet's saying: "And the milk-foal (young camel), if tied in a yoke, cannot withstand the assault of the strong adult camels." [78]

book_title: Ar-Radd al-Mufhim 'ala man Khalafa al-'Ulama wa Tashaddada wa Ta'assaba wa Alzama al-Mar'ah an Tastura Wajhaha wa Kaffayha wa Awjaba wa lam Yaqna' bi-Qawlihim: Innahu Sunnah wa Mustahabbah
text: And in the following research is confirmation of what was mentioned earlier of the Sheikh's ignorance—and those who followed his course—of the science of Hadith and the methods of its criticism, authentication, and weakening according to correct scientific rules, and their partisanship against the Hadith of the Prophet (peace be upon him) in support of their Madhhab, opinion, and desire. And Allah is the one whose help is sought. The Eighth Research: Confirming the authenticity of his saying (peace be upon him): (Authentic) "If a woman reaches menstruation, it is not correct that anything be seen of her except her face and her hands." I say, and with Allah is the assistance: The people [opponents] rushed to criticize the text of this Hadith and weaken it, opposing in that those who strengthened it among the Huffaz of Hadith and its critics: such as Al-Bayhaqi in his "Sunan", Al-Mundhiri in his "Targhib", Al-Dhahabi in his "Tahdhib", and others. Their methods in doing so varied; some of them were content with mentioning one path and weakening it, and some exceeded that as you will see. But they all agreed on quoting what was said about the narrator regarding criticism (*Jarh*) without the authentication (*Ta'dil*) (1). Indeed, some of them deceived and misled that there is no authenticator, and even that he is in the utmost degree of weakness such that he is not used for support (*Istish-had*), and this is a sheer lie. They also all agreed on opposing the rule of scholars in strengthening a Hadith

Even if there are among them those who have some knowledge of it, they have transgressed against the Sunnah and deviated from the truth by following forefathers and schools of thought (*Madhahib*). The explanation of that is from several aspects: First: That even though I had documented the Hadith in this book of mine from the Hadith of Aisha, Asma bint Umays, and Qatada, explaining the defect of the chains of the first two and the disconnection (*Irsal*) of the third, the majority of them concealed this fact and misled their readers that I only used the Hadith of Aisha alone as proof and that I did not explain the weakness of its chain. It is not so, as is written in the book and will be explained now. Among that majority: Sheikh Al-Tuwaijri, Ibn Uthaymeen, Al-Shanqiti in "Al-Adwa" (6 / 597), and others. It was incumbent upon them—had they been fair—to clarify the point of disagreement between me and them and not to mislead them contrary to reality, bearing the burden of those who state explicitly like the author of "Hijabuki Ukhti Al-Muslimah" (Your Hijab, My Muslim Sister), for she said (p. 33): "As for the group that permitted uncovering women's faces, it did not (sic) use as evidence except the Hadith of Abu Dawood..." She is in that imitating Al-Tuwaijri in this denial (p. 236). It seems from her definition of the Mursal Hadith that she understands absolutely nothing of the science of terminology. Second: That it is not permissible for them to limit themselves to quoting the sayings of those who criticize the narrator without the sayings of those who oppose them, especially when they are in the process of refuting their opponents,

for this contradicts the scientific integrity entrusted to them, as is apparent. Sheikh Abdul Qadir Al-Sindi—may Allah guide him—took the lead in this concealment. He added to it that he misled the readers that the concealment was the action of Al-Dhahabi, while he is innocent of it. Also, he did not mention from the three Hadiths—following Al-Shanqiti, Al-Tuwaijri, and Ibn Uthaymeen—except the Hadith of Aisha. He said after mentioning its known disconnection (p. 13 - 14): "I say: In its chain is another damaging defect, which is that Sa'id bin Bashir is *Munkar al-Hadith* (narrates denounced hadith). Imam Al-Dhahabi said..." Then he blackened six lines all of criticism phrases and commented on it attributing to: Mizan Al-I'tidal by Imam Al-Dhahabi 2 / 128. I say: If the readers return to this source from which Al-Sindi quoted those phrases, they will find immense wonder and strange audacity in deception and misleading. Al-Dhahabi did not mention any of the sayings of those who criticized him, which means he is acceptable to him. I say: These texts from these Imams - and from the sources Al-Sindi referred the readers to - confirm with all clarity that he was deceiving the readers, because they do not indicate that this Sa'id is very weak and unfit for citation. Rather, if they do not indicate that he is average and his Hadith is used as evidence, they at least indicate that he is considered (*Yu'tabar*) and strengthened by others. This is what Al-Zayla'i explicitly stated in "Nasb Al-Rayah" (1 / 74) - after mentioning some of what was said about him as previously stated -: "And the least state of someone like this is to be used for support (*Yustash-had bihi*)." This Hisham is Ibn Abi Abd Allah Al-Dastuwa'i, and he is trustworthy and firm (*Thiqah Thabt*) from the narrators of the two Sheikhs [Bukhari and Muslim]. I say: This is strong corroboration from Hisham for Sa'id, indicating that Sa'id memorized the text of the Hadith but erred in attributing its chain to Aisha, due to Hisham contradicting him, for he [Hisham] did not go beyond Qatada. Thus, his chain is authentic Mursal, because Qatada is a prominent Tabi'i. Al-Hafiz said in "At-Taqrib": Trustworthy, firm. [85]

text: Then, the ruling of the Mursal Hadith applies to it if it has witnesses, and this is what will be explained. It is from the ignorance of some of those clinging to this science that after severely weakening the narration of Sa'id bin Bashir from Qatada from Khalid bin Durayk from Aisha, he returned to rely on it to strike down this authentic Mursal narration of Qatada. He said: "Since Qatada narrated the Hadith from Khalid bin Durayk from Aisha, it is not impossible that he omitted Khalid and Aisha and mentioned the Hadith as Mursal, since Qatada is a Mudallis." Thus said Al-Adawi in his "Hijab" (p. 72) and Al-Anbari followed him in his booklet (p. 25). Reflect on how he affirmed the narration of Qatada from Khalid... after severely weakening it, and used it to interpret the authentic narration of Hisham from Qatada? Is this not playing on two ropes or weighing with two scales? As for us, we preferred this authentic Mursal narration of Qatada due to the strength of its chain, following the science of Hadith, although we believe that this does not weaken our argument at all, because both the Mursal and connected narrations support each other in text. And witnessing to them is the third Hadith from Asma bint Umays mentioned in the book (p. 58). Al-Adawi did with it what Al-Sindi did with the Hadith of Aisha; he announced (p. 70) that its weakness is severe, then outlined three defects for it, none of which supports his aforementioned claim: [86]

book_title: Ar-Radd al-Mufhim 'ala man Khalafa al-'Ulama wa Tashaddada wa Ta'assaba wa Alzama al-Mar'ah an Tastura Wajhaha wa Kaffayha wa Awjaba wa lam Yaqna' bi-Qawlihim: Innahu Sunnah wa Mustahabbah
text: The First: Ibn Lahi'ah. I had mentioned it in "Al-Hijab" and explained that he is used for citation, which is the practice among the Huffaz like Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, as will come (p. 96). The Second: Iyad bin Abdullah. He mentioned the scholars' disagreement regarding him and that most of them weakened him. This, as you see, does not mean he is severely weak; rather, he is like Ibn Lahi'ah, as indicated by Al-Hafiz's statement in "At-Taqrib": "There is leniency in him." That is why Al-Adawi avoided him. The Third: The narrator's saying: "I think it is from Asma..." He said: "And this weakens the chain." I say: No, because what is meant is: Preponderant belief (*Zann Rajih*), which is obligatory to act upon—as established in the science of Usul. Furthermore, the mentioned statement only appeared in Al-Bayhaqi's narration, contrary to Al-Tabarani's narration in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Awsat" though the path is one, and contrary to his narration in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir" from another path from Ibn Lahi'ah. Then suppose this statement is established in the narration, from where do you get that it implies the severe weakness you claimed? For the apparent meaning is that he thinks—meaning: the narrator—that the Hadith is from Asma or another Companion. The worst possibility is that he doesn't know if it is connected from a Companion or Mursal. Does that make the chain very weak? Or is it desires that blind and deafen? Perhaps what supports what I mentioned of preponderant belief is that Ubayd bin Rifa'ah, the narrator from Asma, is known for his narration from her [87]

text: Among that is that the alluded one [Al-Anbari] criticized our friend Ali Al-Halabi because he cited in strengthening the Hadith of Aisha the statement of Al-Hafiz in "Al-Talkhis": "And it has a witness narrated by Al-Bayhaqi..." and he mentioned its chain with the Hadith of Asma, and Al-Hafiz's silence regarding it. So our friend said following it (p. 39): "As if he considers it Hasan by it, as is known from his methodology, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him. For a Muhaddith does not cite a witness except for what can be mended in his view, otherwise what benefit does the witness provide if it is useless?" The alluded one criticized him with the summary (p. 16): "That the ancient Muhaddithin, and among them the contemporaries, continue to mention weak or fabricated Hadith and cite its witnesses which only increase it in weakness upon weakness, and no one said: that by doing so they improve the Hadith." Then he mentioned six examples of that: one from "Al-La'ali" by Al-Suyuti and the others from my books "Al-Da'ifah" and "Al-Irwa". Then he answered a question he posed himself, the summary of which is: "That the citation of weak paths by Muhaddithin is only to draw attention to their weakness (1)." I say: This is a false criticism indicating extreme ignorance of this noble science and its principles. For strengthening a Hadith by numerous paths—provided their weakness is not severe—is a known matter and a trodden path among the scholars of Hadith, needing no proof (1).

text: It is the *Hasan Li-Ghayrihi* (Good due to other factors) Hadith which At-Tirmidhi frequently mentions in his "Sunan" and discussed in "Al-Ilal" which is at its end (10 / 457). My books are overflowing with this type of Hadith and reminders of it, especially the "Sahihah" ones. Likewise the quoting from biographical books and their differentiation between the weak narrator who is cited for support and others who are not cited due to the severity of their weakness. The examples he mentioned differ completely from the Hadith of Asma which Al-Hafiz cited as witness and my friend used for strength, from two aspects: One: That they—meaning: the examples—are severely weak, so they are not fit for witnessing. The other: That those who cited them followed them with an explanation of their severe weakness. So where is this compared to the action of Al-Hafiz, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him, which the alluded one rejected? For Al-Hafiz did not explain its weakness, and had he done so, it would not be correct to liken it to those examples because it is not severely weak. As for his aforementioned answer, it confirms his ignorance of this science because he did not explain the reason for alerting to the weakness and its fruit. The answer is known partly at least from the foregoing, which is that if the weakness is slight and its paths are numerous, the Hadith is strengthened and it becomes obligatory to act upon it, like this Hadith of ours. Otherwise, it would be *Gharib* (strange/unsupported), not permissible to act upon, nor even to narrate without explaining its weakness. This is what the majority of authors have neglected, for they are lenient in narrating weak Hadiths without explaining their weakness, as Al-Tuwaijri did in the ten preceding examples, and he and others ignored the strengthening of this Hadith by its paths. [90]

So I say - and Allah's help is sought against the emerging generation of this time -: The non-validity of Qatada's Mursal is not a point of contention. We see, following Al-Bayhaqi and others, that it does get strengthened, and this is the explicit statement of the aforementioned person: "And it is correct..." etc. But due to his novelty, he did not remain firm on it, so he contradicted it by saying: "However, those missed..." By it, their saying is preferred over the saying of Ibn Mas'ud, and the opposition by it falls, and the saying of Al-Bayhaqi and those who followed him remains sound, and they are the majority of the Companions and Imams as previously explained in a way you will not find elsewhere. text: "And the Weak [Hadith] according to them is of two types: Weak which is not prohibited to act upon, and it resembles the Hasan in the terminology of At-Tirmidhi. And Weak with a weakness that necessitates its rejection, and it is the Flimsy (Wahi). A man might be weak according to them due to frequent mistakes in his hadith while the predominant [trait] in him is correctness, [so they narrate his hadith] for consideration and support (1). text: "And the Mursal narrations, if their paths are numerous and free from intentional collusion or unintentional agreement, are definitively authentic. Transmission is either truth matching the report or a lie where its author intentionally lied or erred. So when it is free from intentional lying and error, it is truth without doubt. If the hadith comes from two directions or directions (I say: like this hadith of ours) and it is known that the reporters did not collude on fabricating it, and it is known that such agreement does not happen unintentionally by chance, it is known to be authentic. Like a person reporting an incident that occurred and mentioning details of sayings and actions in it, and another person comes, known not to have colluded with the first, and mentions what the first mentioned of details of sayings and actions. It is known definitively that that incident is true in general. For if each of them had lied about it intentionally or by error, it would not happen habitually that each of them brings those details which habit prevents two agreeing upon without collusion from one to his companion. (He said:) By this way, the generality of what is transmitted with multiple different directions of ignorance regarding this aspect is known, even if one of them is not sufficient either due to its disconnection (Irsal) or the weakness of its transmitter." (He said:) And this principle should be known, for it is useful in being certain about many transmitted reports in Hadith, Tafsir, Maghazi (battles), and what is transmitted of people's sayings and actions and other than that [97]. Therefore, if the hadith in which that occurs is narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, from two aspects with the knowledge that one of them did not take it from the other, it is asserted that it is true, especially if it is known that its transmitters are not those who intentionally lie, but rather forgetfulness and error are feared from one of them. Al-Hafiz Al-Ala'i mentioned something similar to this last section of his speech, may Allah have mercy on him, in "Jami' Al-Tahsil" (p. 38) and added: It rises by their sum to the degree of Hasan because then what is feared of the narrators' poor memory is removed, and each of them is supported by the other. And similar is in "Muqaddimat Ibn As-Salah" and its "Mukhtasar" by Ibn Kathir. Then Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, said (p. 352): And in the likes of this, benefit is derived from the narration of the unknown (Majhul) and the one with poor memory and the Mursal hadith (1) and similar to that. Therefore, the people of knowledge used to write such hadiths and say: It is suitable for witnesses and consideration what is not suitable for other than it. Then he mentioned the saying of Abu Ahmed: "I might write the man's hadith to consider it" and gave Ibn Lahi'ah as an example for it as preceded in his previous speech (p. 96).

I saw one of them come to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "There is no Zakat on wealth until a year passes over it." So he weakened it from its four paths while he knows that Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar and others strengthened it. He also knows that the practice of the Rightly Guided Caliphs was upon it. Yet he paid no heed to all of that, even though he missed an authentic path which he did not mention. It is strange that this one and his likes from the contemporaries resent intensely some students when they exercise Ijtihad (independent reasoning) in some Fiqh issues - while they are not qualified for Ijtihad - then these resentful ones forget themselves when they fall into the likes of what they denounced by their authenticating and weakening of hadiths while they are not people of Ijtihad in it. (O you who have believed, why do you say what you do not do. Great is hatred in the sight of Allah that you say what you do not do) [As-Saff: 2 & 3]. The Ninth Research: Interpretation of the Verse of Adornment (Zinah): (...except what appears thereof). After we have proven the authenticity of this hadith according to the methodology of the people of Hadith and the rules of its scholars firstly, and by the declaration of some of them regarding its strength secondly, and without any significant opponent to them thirdly, I want to clarify to our noble readers that it is then suitable to be an explanation for the saying of the Exalted: (and not expose their adornment except that which [necessarily] appears thereof). So his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, in it: "It is not right for anything to be seen of her" is an explanation of His saying: (and not expose their adornment) meaning: the places of adornment from their bodies and not their clothes as preceded. And his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, in it: "except her face and her hands" is an explanation of His saying: (except what appears) meaning: her face and her hands. So the prohibited in the verse is the prohibited in the hadith, and the excepted in it is the excepted in the hadith. And Allah the Great spoke the truth when He said: (And We revealed to you the message that you may make clear to the people what was sent down to them) [An-Nahl: 44]. From here appears the precision of understanding of the Translator of the Quran (Ibn Abbas) and those with him from the noble Companions when they interpreted the exception in it as the face and hands [102]

And this was hidden from us when we authored the book, then we realized that in the new edition (p. 51 - 56) and here. So praise be to Allah by whose grace good deeds are completed. On this occasion, I must list the names of the Companions referred to, mentioning some of those who extracted it and those who authenticated some of it, so that the readers may know the ignorance of those who opposed them or denied anything of it or misled those who adhered to it.

1 - Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her. Abdur-Razzaq, Ibn Abi Hatim, "Al-Durr Al-Manthur", Ibn Abi Shaybah, and Al-Bayhaqi. And Ibn Hazm authenticated it.

text: Doubts and their Answer: To complete the benefit, I must narrate the doubts of the opponents regarding this authentic hadith and clarify their frailty - nay, their falsity - so I say: The First Doubt: One of the virtuous people considered it unlikely - then those with no knowledge imitated him - that Asma bint Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with them, would enter upon the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, wearing thin clothes. One of those pseudo-scholars who rush to write about what they do not master added to that, blackening seven pages of his booklet explaining the jealousy (Ghayrah) of Asma's husband - who is Az-Zubair Ibn Al-Awwam - and her shyness from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and her observance of her husband's right, which has no relation to the subject at all except for deception and fallacy coupled with exaggeration in raising the non-infallible to the rank of infallibility. After this we say: The answer is from two aspects: First: That the mentioned unlikelihood has no relation to the text (Matn) of the hadith which is from his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, and is established from him by the sum of its paths and witnesses and the practice of the Companions and those after them upon it as preceded. So it is not harmed nor is its authenticity weakened by the fact that some of its paths contain what is unlikely or denounced, and its chain is weak as I had explained in my book "Al-Hijab" previously and here as well. So this part of it is left, and what is in it that agreed with the other paths and witnesses is used as evidence. Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, pointed to this [105]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: It has settled in your mind that the Verse is absolute and that the Hadith is not suitable to restrict it. You are in both matters due to the dominance of blind following over you and the lack of investigation. As for the Hadith, discussion on it has preceded and it is authentic. As for the Verse, you have clearly expressed your mistake regarding it when you said (p. 378): The command to lower the gaze is absolute, so it includes everything from which the gaze should be lowered...) Your saying: "absolute" is a mistake that dragged you to reject this authentic hadith, for it is contrary to what the exegetes (Mufassirun) are upon: like Ibn Jarir, Al-Qurtubi, and Ibn Kathir. They said - and the wording is Ibn Kathir's -: This is a command from Allah Almighty to His believing servants to lower their gazes from what is forbidden to them, so they should not look except at what He permitted them to look at...) So in the Verse, then, is what is forbidden to look at and what is permitted for men and women. So your claim of absoluteness is rejected against you, especially since you built upon it the rejection of this authentic hadith or the negation of its indication with the pickaxe of interpretation (Ta'wil) with which you demolished definitive evidences, especially what was from Prophetic Hadith, as you and your imitator did with the hadith of the Khath'amiyyah woman and others - as preceded in "The Sixth Research" (p. 41 - 44) - and with the hadith of Fatima bint Qais - as preceded there (p. 46 - 47) - and he was imitated by one who runs after him without any research or investigation - like Ibn Khalaf and others - then you quoted it [112]

text: from him in your book (3 / 327) submitting and increasing your numbers with him, ignorant or feigning ignorance - I do not know, by Allah - that the Khimar linguistically and legally: is the head cover without the face as Muslims are upon, predecessors and successors - and you are among them. For no matter what I think of you and your likes among the opponents, I do not think you would order your women to cover their faces if they stood for prayer in the house acting upon his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Allah does not accept the prayer of a menstruating woman except with a Khimar" based on your claim that the Khimar is a face cover as well. The point is that lowering [the gaze] is not on its absolute sense as you claimed. Therefore, Ibn Kathir said in the completion of his previous speech: (Authentic/Sahih) "So if it happens that the gaze falls on a forbidden thing unintentionally, he should turn his gaze away from it quickly as Muslim narrated from Jarir who said: I asked the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, about the sudden glance? So he ordered me to divert my gaze" (1). I say: So the Verse, then, like the Hadith, only commands lowering the gaze from what is forbidden. So justice is to say: If the woman's face is among what is forbidden for her to uncover in front of strangers, looking is forbidden for them, and if it is permissible, it is permissible. Were the people fair? The answer regrettably: No. And the proof: That they do not allow a woman to look at a man's face and what is below it

In it: That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to her: (Authentic/Sahih) "Do you like to look at them?". And her saying: So he lowered his shoulders for me so I could look at them. And her saying: And I had no love for looking at them but I loved that women would know my position to him and my place with him. Despite these explicit texts regarding her looking at them, they negated their indication - as is their habit - by saying sometimes: There is nothing in the hadith that she looked at their faces and bodies, but rather she looked at their playing. I say: It suffices the noble reader to imagine this answer for its falsity to appear to him, since it is impossible to separate looking at the attribute, which is playing, and the attributed, which is the player. So Aisha was looking, in their claim, at the playing without the player. Thus let texts be negated. If they had said: She did not look at an 'awrah or did not look at them with a suspicious look or with fear of Fitnah, they would have been correct, for this is what is forbidden between the sexes [114]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: That one of them looks at the 'awrah of the other or at what is not 'awrah but with desire or fear of Fitnah, as preceded from Ibn Abd al-Barr and others. Their sayings have preceded in some previous researches and I will collect them for you soon, Allah willing. Then I saw a very strong speech by Al-Hafiz Ibn Al-Qattan - which I did not see from others of the people of knowledge - agreeing with what I mentioned of fairness on one hand, and meeting in the end with their sayings referred to on the other hand. So I saw not to miss its benefit for the readers. He said, may Allah have mercy on him, in his book (Folio 54 / 2): We have presented in places that permission to show is proof of permission to look. So if we say: It is permissible for a woman to show her face and hands to everyone without the aspect of Tabarruj (display) and without necessity because that is of what appeared of her adornment and of what is difficult to maintain covering in the state of work, then it is permissible for people to look at that from her. Because if looking were forbidden while showing is permissible for her, that would be assisting in sin, exposing to disobedience, and causing Fitnah, tantamount to offering dead meat to an eater who is not compelled. So whoever among the jurists said it is permissible to show, he does not need to establish evidence for the permissibility of looking. Likewise, it should be that whoever did not permit the woman to show and reveal does not need to establish evidence for the prohibition of looking. We have presented that it is permissible for a woman to show her face and hands, so then looking at that is permissible but on the condition that Fitnah is not feared and pleasure is not intended. As for if pleasure is intended, there is no dispute in prohibition [115]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: if he did not intend nor fear... Likewise, there is also no dispute in the permissibility of men showing their hair, arms, and legs in the presence of men and in the presence of women." If you know this, then I say without any hesitation: Indeed, these people who are strict on women, along with their contradicting the Sharia texts and the sayings of the Imams, do not think about what comes out of their mouths or at least do not pay attention to the dimensions of their sayings. Otherwise, how can they imagine that a woman lowers her gaze from the preacher on Friday, for example, while he is preaching, or from the Mufti while she is asking him for a Fatwa? Nay, how is it possible for this Mufti and his likes from sellers not to look at her face and hands while they are dealing with her?" So I say the truth: Indeed, these strict people say what they do not understand and act contrary to what they say. So I fear that the saying of the Lord of the Worlds will encompass them: (O you who have believed, why do you say what you do not do) [As-Saff: 2]. This authentic hadith which we are in the process of repelling doubts from confirms the meaning mentioned in the two mentioned hadiths and adds to them that it declares the permissibility of a man looking at a woman's face and hands as brother Al-Iskandarani himself mentioned. But he did wrong - regrettably - twice: First: That he understood the command to lower the gaze as absolute, and it is not so as preceded from the Imams of Tafsir. And the other: That instead of interpreting the Verse of Lowering with this Hadith - as is the rule [117]

text:
in interpreting the Quran with the Sunnah - he violated the rule and struck the Hadith with it. His striking of it was in two ways: First: He assumed the authenticity of the hadith, and it is authentic in reality according to the people of knowledge who are aware of its paths and witnesses as previously verified in this Eighth Research in a way you will not find a parallel to in another book. And all credit belongs to Allah firstly and lastly. Second: His interpretation of it. That is because interpretation (Ta'wil) of any legal text is not resorted to except when reconciliation is impossible, and the matter is not so in this hadith. Scholars - despite their different specializations and schools - agreed on carrying the absolute on the restricted or the general on the specific - as preceded from Al-Qurtubi - or by the rule of excepting the less from the more as Ibn Hazm says. And to this Ash-Shawkani inclined in "Nayl Al-Awtar" as previously quoted from him (p. 27 - 28). Here now is what I promised you of collecting the previous sayings of scholars who declared what this authentic hadith indicated of the permissibility of a woman uncovering her face and hands and men looking at that from her without desire or suspicion, so that it becomes clear to the noble readers that some opposing Sheikhs are strict on people and deceive their readers and give the illusion that Consensus is contrary to the sayings of the scholars referred to, noting in listing them the date of their deaths so that the continuity of saying that to our day becomes clear to them as well as the continuity of practice upon it. Reminding once again that the purpose of that is only to clarify [118]

what Allah commanded to be clarified of knowledge and forbade concealing, especially after those Sheikhs concealed it from people and inverted legal facts until that led others from the strict ones to oppose them, so one of them authored what he called "Reminding the Companions of the Prohibition of the Niqab". So this is in a valley and those are in a valley, and the truth is between them as I had mentioned similar to it in the introduction to the second edition of "Al-Hijab". So here are the names and next to them the date of death and with them their sayings:

1 - Sa'id bin Jubayr (d. 95): It is not permissible for a Muslim woman to be seen by a stranger unless she has the Qina' over the Khimar and has tightened it over her head and throat (p. 51)

2 - and 3 and 4 - Abu Hanifa (d. 150) and his two companions Abu Yusuf (d. 183) and Muhammad bin Al-Hasan Al-Shaybani (d. 189) and their saying will come soon

5 - Malik bin Anas (d. 179): There is no harm for a woman to eat with other than a Mahram (p. 35)

text:
6 - Abu Ja'far At-Tahawi (d. 321): It was permitted for people to look at what is not prohibited for them of women, at their faces and hands, and that was forbidden regarding the wives of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. This is the saying of Abu Hanifa, Abu Yusuf, and Muhammad (p. 34) [119]

7 - Ibn Abd al-Barr (d. 463): And it is permissible for everyone who looks at her without suspicion and dislike to look at her hands and face (p. 31)

8 - Al-Baghawi in "Sharh As-Sunnah" (d. 516): It is not permissible for a man to look at anything of her except the face and hands except when there is fear of Fitnah (p. 35 - 36)

9 - Al-Zamakhshari (d. 538): There is no harm in showing what was apparent of it like the ring, kohl, and dye (p. 27)

10 - Qadi Iyad (d. 544): Scholars said: It is not obligatory for the woman to cover her face in her path, but rather that is a Sunnah and recommended for her, and it is obligatory for the man to lower his gaze from her in all situations (p. 27 and 40)

11 - Ibn Al-Qattan (d. 628): And we have presented that it is permissible for a woman to show her face and hands, so looking at that is permissible but on the condition that Fitnah is not feared and pleasure is not intended. As for if pleasure is intended, there is no dispute in prohibition (p. 115) [120]

12 - Ibn Muflih Al-Hanbali (d. 763): Our saying and the saying of a group of the Shafi'is and others: That looking at a foreign woman without desire or seclusion [is permissible], so rebuke should not be made against them if they uncover their faces in the road (p. 40)

13 - Ibn Raslan from "Sharh Sunan At-Tirmidhi" (d. 805): Looking at a foreign woman is permissible when Fitnah is secure (p. 27)

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: 15 - A group of contemporary scholars of the four schools of thought. It is stated in "Al-Fiqh 'ala Al-Madhahib Al-Arba'ah": Looking at both of them [face and hands] is permissible when there is security from Fitnah (temptation) (p. 30). I say: In summary, these statements from these eminent scholars agree on two things: First: That a woman's face and hands are not 'awrah (intimate parts to be covered), which is the madhhab of the majority of scholars and a narration from Imam Ahmed as we proved in "The Fifth Research" (p. 27). And the other: That it is permissible to look at that from a woman without desire. So I say: And this should be the madhhab of all other scholars who held the first [opinion] [121]

text: out of necessity, because the saying of prohibition [of looking] cannot be combined with the saying of the permissibility of showing [by the woman], as verified by Ibn Al-Qattan, may Allah have mercy on him, in what I quoted from him earlier (p. 115). This perfectly matches this authentic hadith which explicitly states both matters together. Brother Al-Iskandarani's inability to conceive this is due to his narrow-mindedness and lack of knowledge; otherwise, he would be forced to say that these eminent scholars held a view that is "inconceivable", and I do not think he would reach the point of accusing them of that. Thus, this fourth doubt collapses as well. The Fifth Doubt: One of the virtuous people said: And assuming the authenticity of the hadith, it should be interpreted as being before [the verse of] Hijab (1) because the texts of Hijab abrogate the original rule. This has preceded. So I say: The mentioned interpretation is invalid here for two reasons: First: That there is nothing in those texts that is explicit in indicating the obligation of covering the face and hands so that it can be said that they abrogate the original rule. And the other: That the "texts of Hijab" referred to are divided into two types in terms of their indication: First: What relates to the Hijab of homes where the woman is relaxed in her house. This

text: has no relation to what we are discussing, as is apparent. Moreover, it only contains the verse of Al-Ahzab: (And when you ask [his wives] for something, ask them from behind a partition) [Al-Ahzab: 53], and we have already presented from Ibn Taymiyyah that it is regarding [behavior in] homes. And the other: What relates to the woman when she leaves her house, which is the Jilbab. The texts reported regarding it are also of two types: First: What was a report about women wearing Jilbabs in his time, peace and blessings be upon him. So whatever of this type mentions covering the face - like the hadith of Aisha in the story of Al-Ifk and similar narrations which I mentioned in the chapter "Legitimacy of Covering the Face" - has no relation to the research because it is merely an action that is not suitable to be an abrogator from the original rule to prohibition. This is apparent and not hidden from a fair, knowledgeable jurist, even if some Ph.D. holders were heedless of it. And the other: What was legislation containing a command contrary to what they were upon before. There is nothing of this except the verse of "lowering the Jilbabs" and the verse of "drawing the Khumur over the Juyub", and there is no evidence in them for the prohibition of uncovering the face and hands, neither linguistically nor legally, as previously verified - extensively - later. Indeed, what confirms this to every fair person free from desire and sectarian fanaticism is that those who accept the authenticity of this hadith share with us the view of the permissibility of the Niqab which reveals her eyes - and what is below them even sometimes. So did they contradict [123]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: by that those texts which abrogate [the original rule] according to their claim, or (they are a contentious people)? And to further clarify the invalidity of this doubt, I say: Their intention by their mentioned saying: That this hadith - which is authentic to us and admitted as authentic by them - is abrogated by the verse of Hijab: (they should bring down over themselves from their outer garments) [Al-Ahzab: 59]. Some of their imitators have explicitly stated this, like the one called (Raghda) in her "Hijab" (p. 34), and Sheikh Al-Baleeh and Al-Sabuni and others as in "Al-Awda" (3 / 343). This - by Allah - is among the most wondrous of wonders from those virtuous people, because the verse does not contain an explicit indication of the obligation of covering as I mentioned just now. If it indicates that, it is only by implication of generality (1) - it cannot be otherwise - whether in terms of the word (Jilbab) or (Idna/lowering). So the hadith shares this indication in its first part: "If a woman reaches menstruation, it is not right for anything to be seen of her..." for it means nothing should be seen of her. Then he added to the verse saying: "except her face and her hands". This is explicit that generality is not intended. If the verse was general, the hadith specifies it; otherwise, it explains it, as He, the Exalted, said: (And We revealed to you the message that you may make clear to the people what was sent down to them) [An-Nahl: 44]. This is very clear. I do not know how the claim of

[124].

text: abrogation of the hadith by the verse settled in the minds of these opponents? For this contradicts what is established in the science of Usul al-Fiqh. Their likeness is only like one who might say: That the hadith: (Authentic/Sahih) "The hand of the thief is not cut off except for a quarter of a dinar and upwards" (Agreed upon) is abrogated by His saying, Exalted is He: ([As for] the thief, the male and the female, amputate their hands) [Al-Ma'idah: 38]. And that his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding the sea: (Authentic/Sahih) "Its water is purifying and its dead animals are lawful" - and what is in its meaning - is abrogated by His saying, Exalted is He: (Prohibited to you are dead animals) [Al-Ma'idah: 3]. Examples of this are many, very many. Therefore, Ash-Shawkani explicitly stated the exception of the face and hands, using this hadith as evidence as previously mentioned. Then a third aspect occurred to me: It is that the mentioned interpretation would only be valid on the assumption that the proof in our issue is merely remaining on the original rule, which is permissibility. Then the mentioned interpretation would be valid. But since the reality is not so - because the discussion is about this hadith assuming its authenticity - the mentioned interpretation is invalid. For how can it be interpreted as being before Hijab or Jilbab while it is with it in prohibiting the woman from not covering with the Jilbab? Meaning: in abrogating the original rule. And it adds to the verse of Jilbab that it excepted the face and hands from it - as previously explained - and this is very clear. By this, the fall of the speech of brother Al-Iskandarani in his book (3 / 344) also becomes clear, with which he tried to support the mentioned interpretation with words he quoted from me regarding circular gold, imagining it is proof against me due to heedlessness of the difference between what is the original rule so it is abrogated by the general text, and between the abrogating text itself coupled with an exception indicating [125]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: the persistence of what is in it upon the original rule. They have all neglected this fact. Their likeness in that is only like one who prohibits gold absolutely and silk for women despite his exception, peace and blessings be upon him, for them from the prohibition in the authentic hadith through its paths: "These two are forbidden for the males of my Ummah, lawful for its females," interpreting it as being [the rule] based on the original state. Would anyone of the people of knowledge do this? I do not think so. But these opponents have done the like of it in this hadith of ours, so they abrogated the specific with the general. And Allah's help is sought. What preceded just now is also the answer to a question posed by the one known as Ibn Khalaf in his "Nazarat" (p. 87). He said with extreme ignorance: Why does he not hold the jurisprudential rule: If a prohibition and a permission conflict, the prohibition is prioritized? Brother Al-Iskandarani supported him (3 / 345 - 346) with speech of no benefit, some of it related to the report abrogating the original rule - and you knew its answer - and the other to this rule. The answer is the same answer, i.e., not here. It is like the first rule related to prioritizing the report abrogating the original rule. Both rules are correct but placed in the wrong place. Whoever does not believe let him apply them to the example of silk and gold for women if he wishes. The summary of the answer to this fifth doubt: The people turned away from dealing with this hadith - assuming they accept its authenticity, and it is authentic to us - with the correct scientific Usul principles, among which is: Abrogation is not resorted to [126]

text: except when reconciliation is impossible, and among which is interpreting the general by the specific. Scholars have said: It is not lawful for anyone to say regarding a verse or hadith: They are abrogated and acting upon them is not permissible, except with a clear text or consensus. Ibn Hazm mentioned this in "Al-Ihkam fi Usul Al-Ahkam" and that there is consensus of scholars on it (3 / 130). He detailed that in "Chapter on how to know the abrogated and the abrogator from what is not abrogated" (4 / 83 - 92), so let whoever wishes refer to it for it is important. The Tenth Research: Is it obligatory upon women to cover their faces due to the corruption of the times and blocking the means (Sadd al-Dhari'ah)? I say: This question is posed today by many blind followers who do not look at Sharia issues through the lens of Sharia and its evidences, and do not refer judgment upon disagreement to the Book and the Sunnah, but rather to the opinions and ideas that have settled in their souls. If they had responded to Allah and the Messenger when He calls them to what gives them life, they would have rested and given rest. But they turned away from that and from the sayings of their Imams that they must all - men and women - lower their gazes according to the detailed explanation preceded. They resorted to imitating some imitators who came after the Imams with a cause ('illa) they innovated, which is their saying: "on the condition of security from Fitnah" (1) - meaning: being tempted by her - otherwise covering them is obligatory upon her.

[127].

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: One of them - who has no Fiqh or insight - exaggerated and attributed that to the agreement of the Imams, may Allah be pleased with them (1). For what comes to mind from the word: "The Imams" is only the four Mujtahid Imams, and there is no knowledge from any of them that they stipulated the mentioned condition. That does not befit their knowledge as will come. Rather, the apparent meaning of what was mentioned earlier (p. 119 - 121) of their saying regarding the permissibility of looking at that from women contradicts it. Therefore, one of the great followers of Abu Hanifa from the later generations, Muhammad bin Ahmed bin Abi Sahl Abu Bakr Shams Al-A'immah As-Sarakhsi, who died around the year five hundred, did not turn to the mentioned condition. Allama Al-Lucknawi described him in "Al-Fawa'id" (108) as: He was an Imam, Allama, Hujjah (Proof), Mutakallim (Theologian), debater, Usuli (jurist of principles), Mujtahid. Ibn Kamal Pasha counted him among the Mujtahids in issues. I say: This As-Sarakhsi - with his leadership - explicitly stated - following Abu Hanifa and his two companions and At-Tahawi as preceded - the permissibility of looking at foreign women, even though he mentioned that the prohibition of looking is due to fear of Fitnah and that Fitnah in looking at her face is greater than at other parts of her body. He said in his book "Al-Mabsut" (10 / 152 - Dar Al-Ma'rifah Beirut):

text: "But we take the saying of Ali and Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, for reports have come granting permission to look at her face and hands... (1) if the look is not out of desire. But if he knows that if he looks he will desire, it is not lawful for him to look at anything of her." I say: And his saying: "Ali" perhaps is a slip of the pen or an error from the scribe or printer, for we did not find in the reports As-Sarakhsi referred to anything from Ali. They are from six Companions, and I have mentioned their names previously (p. 103 - 104), among them Aisha and Ibn Umar. So I fear it might be distorted from "Aisha". The wording of her hadith with Al-Bayhaqi (2 / 226) is: (Weak) "(what appears thereof): The face and hands." Its chain is weak but it has another path with similar meaning with Ibn Abi Shaybah and others. It is witnessed by the Athar of Ibn Umar with the wording: (Authentic/Sahih) "The apparent adornment: The face and hands." Ibn Abi Shaybah reported it (4 / 284) with an authentic chain from him, then he narrated similar to it from Ibn Abbas and its chain is authentic as well.
