Therefore, I did not deem it permissible to mention them, although they are proof for us, and because we have mentioned in our book enough authentic reports to dispense with using flimsy reports as evidence, contrary to our opponents who habitually use whatever reports they find, good or bad 
[129].

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: As for the comment of Brother Al-Iskandarani on As-Sarakhsi's saying: "Ali and Ibn Abbas", saying (3 / 420): He refers to what was narrated from them, may Allah be pleased with them, in the interpretation of the saying of the Exalted: (except what appears thereof): as Kohl and the ring. Imam Akmal Al-Din Muhammad Al-Babarti Al-Hanafi clarified in Sharh Al-Inayah 'ala Al-Hidayah "that the indication of their saying on the face and hands is not clear. He said: Since it is apparent that the place of Kohl is the eye not the whole face, and likewise the place of the ring is the finger not the whole hand, and the claim is the permissibility of looking at the face of the foreign woman entirely and at her hands entirely. End quote. (10 / 24)" I say: This comment and the deduction in it is wrong from several aspects: First: That it assumes the adornment mentioned in the verse is the adornment itself and not its place. This is a mistake contradicting what verifying exegetes and others are upon - as preceded (p. 27 - 32). There is no clearer proof of that than the fact that no one says it is not permissible for a woman to show her jewelry to a stranger while they are not on her body, just as no one says the opposite, i.e., that she shows their places on her body while the adornment is not on them. Second: What confirms the error is that it is impossible to see the ring on the finger except by seeing the hand. So it is proven that what is intended in the Athar is the place and not the adornment itself. [130]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: Third: That it is based on the wording mentioned by the commentator: "Kohl and the ring". That is a mistake from him for two reasons: First: That it is weak and not authentic. The commentator himself narrated that in another place (3 / 431). The authentic established wording from Ibn Abbas and others is: "The face and hands" as preceded recently, so the indication is very clear. And the other: That the one coupled with Ibn Abbas in As-Sarakhsi's phrase is Ibn Umar or Aisha - as I preferred earlier - and their wording is exactly the authentic wording from Ibn Abbas as you saw. Accordingly, it is not permissible to interpret their wording - or the wording of one of them - based on the weak wording from Ibn Abbas, as is apparent and not hidden from the people of knowledge. Thus, the mentioned deduction falls from its foundation, and it appears that the mentioned comment has no value from a scientific perspective because it is based on gathering without verification and inspection and distinguishing the authentic from the weak of narrations. Here a question poses itself - as they say today -: Why did Brother Muhammad bin Ismail prefer the weak wording over the authentic wording? The answer: From several aspects: First: Because it fits the words of Al-Babarti Al-Hanafi. Second: Because he does not know the difference between the two wordings in terms of narration (Riwayah) though he knows the difference between them in terms of understanding (Dirayah). [131]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: Third: That he does not know the authenticity of either of them because he was entangled in a long research by Sheikh Abdul-Qadir Al-Sindi - may Allah reform him - about the Athar of Ibn Abbas. He hummed in it around this weak wording and elaborated on clarifying its weakness with exaggeration in weakening a narration - with boring repetition and disturbing confusion in judgment - in a way there is no room to explain here. And he concealed this authentic wording and did not address mentioning its chain, but he pointed to it (p. 18) saying: And here are other chains no less in degree of weakness and denunciation (Nakara). Thus he said, may Allah guide him, and he is lying in that. His lie deceived our good brother, so he quoted his words in his book (3 / 263 - 265) and approved him in it due to his ignorance, like others, of this science. Nay, he titled it saying: "Verification of the Athars attributed to Ibn Abbas may Allah be pleased with them". He followed that with a research titled "The answer to the saying of Ibn Abbas assuming its attribution to him" (3 / 267). Therefore, I see myself compelled to cite its authentic chain so that the readers may be clear about it firstly, and know the truthful from the liar and the scholar from the ignorant secondly, and so that they are not deceived by every croaker speaking nonsense about what he does not know thirdly. And Allah's help is sought. Ibn Abi Shaybah, may Allah have mercy on him, said in "Al-Musannaf" (4 / 283): Ziyad bin Abi Al-Rabi' told us, from Salih Al-Dahhan, from Jabir bin Zaid, from Ibn Abbas: (Authentic/Sahih) "(and not expose their adornment): He said: The hand and the patch of the face." [132]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: I say: And this is an authentic chain that no one weakens except an ignorant or biased person, for its men are trustworthy. I begin with Ibn Abi Shaybah's Sheikh, Ziyad bin Al-Rabi'. He is trustworthy without any significant disagreement, and Al-Bukhari used him as proof in his "Sahih". Salih Al-Dahhan is trustworthy as well, as Ibn Ma'in said. Ahmed said in "Al-Ilal" (2 / 33): There is no harm in him. Ibn Hibban mentioned him in "Al-Thiqat" (6 / 457). As for Jabir bin Zaid - who is Abu Al-Sha'tha Al-Azdi - he is too famous to need mentioning, among the trustworthy Tabi'in known for taking from Ibn Abbas. The Two Sheikhs (Bukhari and Muslim) extracted for him, and Ibn Abbas testified for him that he is among the scholars of the Book of Allah - as preceded (p. 50). He is the one who received from Ibn Abbas the interpretation of (Idna) by his saying: "She lowers the Jilbab to her face and does not strike with it" - as preceded (p. 50). And he is the one who used to order Hind bint Al-Muhallab to place the Khimar on the forehead, meaning: not on the face as At-Tuwaijri and his imitators claim. Sa'id bin Jubayr followed him in narrating from Ibn Abbas with Ibn Abi Shaybah as well, and in its chain is a weak narrator. Abdullah bin Umar followed Ibn Abbas with an authentic chain, and his wording matching [133]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: the authentic wording of Ibn Abbas just mentioned preceded. So let no one be deceived after this by the saying of the author of "Kashshaf Al-Qina'" (1 / 243) - after attributing it to Ibn Abbas and Aisha -: Al-Bayhaqi narrated it and in it is weakness. Al-Iskandarani approved him (3 / 431). For its chain with Al-Bayhaqi is different from its chain with Ibn Abi Shaybah. Moreover, his saying: "its chain" in the singular implies that Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from both of them with one chain, and this is contrary to reality. For he narrated it (2 / 225) from the path of Sa'id bin Jubayr from Ibn Abbas, then from the path of Ikrimah from him. So these are two paths. Then he narrated it from the path of Ata bin Abi Rabah from Aisha. So this is a third chain. So let the noble reader reflect on how much bias and injustice against this noble science is in the transmission of this brother Al-Iskandarani - and others who delved into what they do not master? We have taken our readers a little or a lot away from the subject of research, so apologies to them, although in that there are some benefits they might not find in other than this place. So let us return to what we were in the process of, discussing the condition placed by those imitators, opposing in that the one who was a Mujtahid in the Madhhab, the Allama As-Sarakhsi (1)

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: let alone other earlier and later scholars up to our time who continued to hold the permissibility of looking at a woman's face and hands if the looker is secure from Fitnah. I have mentioned their sayings regarding that recently (p. 119 - 121), so let whoever wishes to remember review them. They all converge on the fact that men must not look at women's faces when they fear Fitnah. So how ignorant is that author who attributed to the Imams their agreement that a woman must cover her face so that men are not tempted by her, while among them were those in the sixth century and after - like Qadi Iyad, An-Nawawi, Ibn Muflih, and Ash-Shawkani - who said as preceded: It is not obligatory for a woman to cover her face in her path, and that rebuke should not be made against them if they uncover their faces in the road. It is as if that author and those of his ilk - from the imitators like Al-Sabuni and Al-Ghawji and their likes - imagine that Fitnah was secure in those centuries and that Allah, Blessed and Exalted, did not place preventions and barriers before it through what He obligated on women of Hijab and what He commanded both sexes of lowering the gaze, and said regarding that: (That is purer for your hearts and their hearts) [Al-Ahzab: 53]. They forget that human nature is one in every time as came in the Quran: (Beautified for people is the love of that which they desire - of women and sons...) [Al-Imran: 14] the verse. And that they only differ in piety and following the rulings of Allah Almighty. Among that is the story of Al-Fadl bin Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, with [135]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: the beautiful Khath'amiyyah woman and his repeated looking at her while he was a pilgrim, and how the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, sufficed with turning his face away from her and did not command her to cover her face. This is the time of Fitnah (temptation) with her and blocking the means (Sadd al-Dhari'ah) from her according to their claim, yet he, peace and blessings be upon him, did not do that. So his action, peace and blessings be upon him, indicates the invalidity of what they went to of obligating covering, as is apparent due to the agreement of scholars that delaying clarification from the time of need is not permissible. Therefore, one of them did badly when he said - to escape this apparent proof -: Perhaps the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, commanded her after that meaning: to cover her face. So I say following Ibn Umar - or another from the Salaf -: Put (perhaps) with that star (meaning: discard it), because it contains a negation of the Sunnah, which includes his approval, peace and blessings be upon him. For there is nothing that he, peace and blessings be upon him, remained silent about and approved except that it is possible for every debater to invalidate it with such a saying. Like the hadith of that man who entered Ihram for Umrah in his Jubbah after perfuming himself, so he, peace and blessings be upon him, commanded him to take off the Jubbah and wash off the perfume, and it is in the "Two Sahihs". Scholars used it as evidence - including the Hanbalis - that there is no ransom (Fidyah) on him. Ibn Qudamah said in "Al-Mughni" (3 / 262): Because the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, did not order the man to pay a ransom. So does the one referred to here say as he said there: Perhaps the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, ordered him after that? Or is it measuring with two measures and weighing with two scales? And Allah's help is sought [136]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: And know, O reader, that the hadiths from which scholars derived - according to their different schools - many rulings from his approval, peace and blessings be upon him, are too many to count. If a researcher set out to collect them in a book and discuss them in terms of narration and understanding, it would result in a volume or more. From here appears the danger of this wishful thinking (Tarajji) which is motivated only by blind following and defense of the Madhhab and opinion. Among that is the story of the majestic Companion Mu'awiyah bin Al-Hakam As-Sulami, may Allah be pleased with him, who preserved for us the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, to the slave girl: "Where is Allah?" and her answer: "In the heaven" and his testimony, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding her: "Indeed she is a believer." For he, may Allah be pleased with him, was praying behind him, peace and blessings be upon him, one day - and he was new to Islam - so he called out: "Oh, bereft of my mother! What is the matter with you looking at me?" to the end of the story in "Sahih Muslim" and others, and it is extracted in "Al-Irwa" (2 / 111 / 390). Scholars used it as evidence, including the Shafi'is: "That the speech of the ignorant in prayer does not invalidate it" with details on that according to them. An-Nawawi said in "Sharh Muslim": Because the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, did not order him to repeat the prayer. Similar was said by Ibn Taymiyyah in "Al-Fatawa" (20 / 366 and 22 / 624). And I only said previously: "And this is the time of Fitnah..." due to the saying of Al-Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him - as in the hadith of Ali in the Book (p. 28 - 6th Edition) -: O Messenger of Allah, why did you twist the neck of your cousin? He said, peace and blessings be upon him: [137]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: "I saw a young man and a young woman, so I did not trust Satan with them." This is explicit that he, peace and blessings be upon him, only did that out of fear of Fitnah as Ash-Shawkani said in "Nayl Al-Awtar" (6 / 97). So whoever does in such a situation contrary to the action of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, has contradicted his guidance, peace and blessings be upon him, and exposed himself to the threat of His saying, Exalted is He: (So let those beware who dissent from the Prophet's order, lest fitnah strike them or a painful punishment) [An-Nur: 63] and his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "...And whoever turns away from my Sunnah is not of me." Agreed upon. So how about if he makes his contradiction a continuous rule until Allah wills? Then Ash-Shawkani, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Ibn Al-Qattan deduced from it the permissibility of looking when secure from Fitnah since he did not order her to cover her face. If Al-Abbas had not understood that looking is permissible, he would not have asked, and if what he understood was not permissible, he would not have approved him on it. Some of those who have no Fiqh answered his not commanding her, peace and blessings be upon him, to cover by saying: If he had commanded her, it would have become obligatory to cover her face, and we did not claim this. See "Hijab Al-Adawi" (p. 99). So I say: From your opinion for the support of which you authored your "Hijab" and refuted your opponent is that covering the face is obligatory upon a woman. So do you mean by your mentioned saying that [138]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: covering is not obligatory upon the Muhrima (woman in Ihram)? If you say that - nay, you explicitly stated that (p. 97) - then you have come with an innovated saying contradicting the way of the believers. For we do not know anyone from the people of knowledge who said covering is obligatory as a principle while not obligatory on the Muhrima even during Fitnah. Otherwise, those you follow would not have needed to fabricate various answers to escape the apparent indication of the hadith on the invalidity of their saying of obligation. The invalidity of those aspects has already been explained on pages (41 - 43 and 135 - 136). Despite this contradiction of all scholars, he contradicted himself once again. For he asserted (p. 81) that it is binding on the slave girl to cover her face if Fitnah is feared as blocking the means (Sadd al-Dhari'ah), while the principle according to him is that it is not binding on her. Yet here he did not say it is binding on the free woman with the realization of fear, while the principle is that it is obligatory upon her according to him. Is this not form the vacillation in the religion of Allah which Abu Mas'ud Al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him, forbade? (1) To escape the apparent indication of the hadith which great scholars stated explicitly and proceeded upon until today as previously verified. And Allah's help is sought. The summary of the speech: Fitnah with women existed in the time of revelation to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and because of that Allah Almighty legislated rulings for both sexes - blocking the means - as previously indicated. If Allah Almighty had willed to obligate women to cover their faces before strangers, He would have done so blocking the means as well (And never is

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: your Lord forgetful) [Maryam: 64]. And He would have revealed to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, to command the Khath'amiyyah woman to cover her face, for this is the time of clarification as preceded. But on the contrary, he, peace and blessings be upon him, wanted to clarify to people in that great scene that blocking the means here is not by prohibiting what Allah made lawful for women to uncover their faces if they wished, but rather by applying the rule: (...lower their gazes) and that by turning Al-Fadl's gaze away from the woman. In my critique, there is no difference between these blind followers obligating women to cover their faces - blocking the means as they claimed - and if someone were to say: It is obligatory upon men to cover their faces - as is the case of the veiled men (Mulaththamun) in some countries - so that women are not tempted by looking at them, blocking the means as well. This is like that. Whoever differentiates has contradicted himself and been biased towards men over women, since they are all partners in the obligation of lowering the gaze. So whoever adds a new ruling on the other without proof from Allah and His Messenger has transgressed and wronged (And Allah does not love the wrongdoers) [Al-Imran: 57]. Here I recall a verse of poetry as if a female jurist represents herself with it saying: Another sinned and I am the punished among you So I am like the index finger of the remorseful And perhaps it is superfluous to mention: That the bulk of this research is with those blind followers who contradicted their Imams in this issue - and the Book and Sunnah with them - and whom the blind followers see as obligatory to imitate because their sayings for the imitators are like the evidences of the Book and Sunnah for the Mujtahids. So just as it is not permissible for those except to follow [140]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: the Book and Sunnah, likewise those, it is not permissible for them except to imitate them. That is what they say and this is the extent of their knowledge. But here they have agreed on contradicting the Book and Sunnah on one hand and the sayings of their Imams on the other. They added to that - insult to injury - so they imitated those whom it is not permissible for them to imitate because they are imitators like them and from their later generations as preceded. And blind following (Taqlid) is not knowledge by agreement of the people of knowledge as Ibn al-Qayyim said in "I'lam Al-Muwaqqi'in" (1 / 51 and 2 293). Abu Al-Hasan As-Sindi narrated in the beginning of his "Hashiyah on Ibn Majah" from As-Suyuti: That the imitator is not called a scholar. Therefore, Al-Marghinani Al-Hanafi called him in "Sharh Al-Hidayah" (6 / 359) "The Ignorant" and narrated the disagreement regarding the permissibility of appointing him to judgeship. Ibn Al-Humam narrated in "Fath Al-Qadir" from Imam Muhammad: That the imitator is not permitted to be a judge. How excellent is the example Imam Shafi'i struck for the imitator when he said: The likeness of the one who seeks knowledge without proof is like a wood gatherer at night carrying a bundle of wood in which is a snake biting him and he does not know. Al-Bayhaqi reported it in "Al-Madkhal" (210 - 211) with an authentic chain from him (1). Among the proof for them in that is his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: Indeed Allah does not take away knowledge by snatching it from the servants, but He takes away knowledge

by taking away the scholars, until when He leaves no scholar, people take ignorant heads who are asked and give fatwas without knowledge (and in a narration: with their opinion), so they go astray and lead astray." Agreed upon, and the wording and the other narration belong to Al-Bukhari (No. 68 - Mukhtasar Al-Bukhari). Refer to "Fath Al-Bari" (13 / 282 - 290) if you wish, for he elaborated on its explanation and clarification of its benefits, and that the intended meaning of his saying: "ignorant heads": is only the blind followers. And the reality in most Islamic countries is a confirmation of this authentic hadith, including what we are dealing with. And Allah's help is sought. Then I say: If those blind followers had any knowledge, they would not have obligated women to cover their faces out of fear that men would be tempted by them while saying: That the principle is the permissibility of unveiling. They would have said: If a woman fears that harm will befall her from some evil men because of her unveiling, then she should not unveil, blocking the means. If they had said this, it would have been acceptable jurisprudence. But to impose that on women generally in every time and place is legislation for which Allah has sent down no authority. Therefore, no scholar of Islam has said it; rather, they said the opposite as we presented from Qadi Iyad, An-Nawawi, Ibn Muflih and other eminent scholars [142]

Summary of the Previous Researches: To summarize what preceded, I say: The following facts have become clear to the noble readers from these enlightening researches:

1 - That those who say it is obligatory for a woman to cover her face and hands do not have a text for that from the Book or Sunnah or Consensus, nay, they do not even have a single authentic explicit narration from the Salaf that must be followed, except for some general or absolute texts which the Sunnah undertook to explain, and the Ummah did not act upon their absolute and general nature. Some of them excepted the face and hands, some excepted half the face, some excepted the eyes from the face, and some excepted one eye. The first group are the most guided by the Book and Sunnah.

2 - Their interpretation of (Al-Khimar), (Al-Idna), (Al-Jilbab), and (Al-I'tijar) contrary to the Prophetic Hadiths, Salafi Athars, and linguistic texts, and even contrary to their interpretation of the verse of women past child-bearing age (Al-Qawa'id).

3 - Their use of weak Hadiths and flimsy and fabricated Athars as evidence for that, whether they know or do not know.

text:
4 - The claim of some of them of Consensus on their opinion while they know the disagreement in it, and they might quote it themselves but they are stubborn. Among those opposing them are the three Imams and with them Ahmed in a narration [143]

5 - They denied authentic explicit texts contrary to their opinion, sometimes by interpreting them and negating their indications, and sometimes by ignoring them or weakening them. And they are all not among the people of authentication and weakening, but they were forced to involve themselves in what they have no knowledge of, so they authenticated and weakened whatever they wished in defense of their opinion.

6 - And perhaps some of them changed a narrator in the chain of narration with another strengthening it, and deleted from the text of the hadith or the scholar's speech what is proof against him, and cited the narration arguing or using it as a witness while it is against him.

7 - Their rush to weaken his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Indeed, if a woman reaches menstruation, it is not right for anything to be seen of her except her face and her hands" and their opposition to the Hadith scholars who strengthened it and to the scientific rules that necessitate its authenticity with justifications and personal opinions unknown to the people of knowledge.

8 - Their agreement on weakening the Athars narrated from the Companions which testify to the hadith, even though some of them have authentic chains like Ibn Abbas and Ibn Umar, and it has seven paths from Ibn Abbas alone.

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text:
9 - Some of them concealing the rest of the paths of the hadith strengthening it, and some of them claiming severe weakness in some of its narrators in preparation to escape from using them as witnesses, and deluding readers that it has no support by referring to some sources while the reality in them belies him [144]

10 - Some of them claiming the abrogation of the hadith by the verse of (Idna) contrary to the scientific rules that necessitate reconciliation by interpreting the general by the specific and the like.

11 - Their clinging to what is not authentic in narration (Riwayah) and knowledge (Dirayah) to reject what is authentic in narration and knowledge. And their adherence to the absolute of the Quran while the Sunnah has restricted it.

12 - Some blind followers negating the evidences of the Book and Sunnah and the sayings of their Imams as well stating the permissibility of a woman uncovering her face by imitating some blind followers who say covering is obligatory blocking the means - according to their claim - contrary to As-Sarakhsi and other scholars to our time.

text: 13 - One of their Sheikhs negating the jurisprudential rule: "Delaying clarification from the time of need is not permissible" and the rule of using his approval, peace and blessings be upon him, and his silence about a thing as evidence to escape the indication of the hadith of the Khath'amiyyah woman on the permissibility of uncovering. These are a number of facts and illusions that the strict opponents fell into - due to their fanaticism for their opinion and neglecting scientific rules, Hadith and Fiqh ones, and turning away from benefiting from the sayings and interpretations of other scholars, their predecessors and successors - which the noble readers can perceive from those ten researches. I wanted to make them visible before their eyes to be a lesson for those who take heed [145]

text: The Conclusion. In this conclusion, I must draw attention to the fact that strictness in religion is evil with no good in it. If the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Good only brings good." Agreed upon. Then likewise strictness is evil that only brings evil. Therefore, Hadiths multiplied and their wordings varied in warning against it. He said, peace and blessings be upon him: (Authentic/Sahih) First: "Religion is ease, and no one overburdens himself in religion except that it overcomes him. So aim for what is right and approach it..." Narrated by Al-Bukhari (No. 39). (Authentic/Sahih) Second: "Beware of excess in religion, for those before you were destroyed by excess in religion." Narrated by the authors of the Sahihs: Ibn Khuzaimah, Ibn Hibban, Al-Hakim, Al-Diya' and others, and it is extracted in "As-Sahihah" (1283). (Authentic/Sahih) Third: "Do not be strict on yourselves, for those before you were destroyed by their strictness on themselves, and you will find their remnants in hermitages and monasteries." Al-Bukhari extracted it in "Al-Tarikh" and others, and I extracted it in "As-Sahihah" (3124). If the matter is so, then the noble readers must have noticed this strictness embodied in what we recounted of their sayings and opinions, among which is their saying: "even her fingernail" and in prayer as well, and what they burdened themselves with in rejecting definitive evidences of the practice of uncovering the face in the centuries witnessed for with goodness, and the testimony of the virtuous Companions [146]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: and Tabi'in and Mujtahid Imams of the permissibility of that. And the saying of Imam Malik, the Imam of the Abode of Migration, is not far from the reader's memory, which is that it is permissible - or no harm - for a woman to eat with other than a Mahram (see p. 35) and other explicit statements of theirs that the face is not 'awrah. So I say: Despite that, Sheikh At-Tuwaijri misleads those who hold this saying - as quoted from him earlier (p. 8) - rather he makes that from heresy in the verses of Allah... (p. 49). Then he is not ashamed to claim Consensus that the woman's face is 'awrah while he himself mentions that the majority of scholars hold otherwise - as preceded (p. 32). His followers in this strictness are many, regrettably. This is from the scientific aspect which everyone who stands on their statements shares with us in knowing. As for the practical aspect, the matter is very strange. Three examples have become available to me: First: A brother-in-law told me that he intended to visit a virtuous Sheikh from those strict ones, but he did not celebrate him nor receive him because his wife was uncovering her face, even though her Hijab was Sharia-compliant in all aspects. And this Sheikh is known for his humility and good manners. So where is this from the saying of Imam Ahmed preceded (p. 9): It is not appropriate for the Faqih to compel people to his Madhhab? [147]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: Second: When I performed Umrah, I and my wife Umm Al-Fadl in the year (1410 AH), we saw many female pilgrims performing Sa'y wearing Niqab. So I advised the men and she advised the women that this is not permissible, and if it is necessary, then you must let down [the cloth], and we mention the Hadith reported regarding that. But we find no response from them. I felt that this is an effect of the strictness of some Sheikhs in the issue of the face. It was incumbent upon them - since they refused but to be strict - to add to that warning the Muhrimas (women in Ihram) against wearing Niqab, for it is very widespread among them as I witnessed in all my Hajj and Umrah trips. I saw in the Mas'a a young man performing Sa'y and beside him a woman wearing Niqab. I approached him and asked him: Is she a Muhrima? He said: Yes. So I said: O my brother, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The Muhrima does not wear Niqab nor..." He did not let me finish the hadith and hastened by saying: This is a disputed issue. I said: My discussion is not about the woman's face but about the Muhrima wearing Niqab. He paid no heed to me and went on performing Sa'y with her. Third: In the mentioned year - after Umrah - it was destined for me to visit the Eastern Province of Saudi Arabia. I gave some lectures there and answered the questions of male and female questioners in writing and by phone. It reached me about some committed women among them that when the hadith: "The Muhrima does not wear Niqab..." reached them, they said: We wear Niqab and do not uncover our faces and we pay Fidyah (ransom). So I said: Glory be to Allah, what ignorance does to its people. Allah has made for them [148]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: a way out: That they cover their faces by letting down [the cloth]. But that is from the effects of the strictness of some Sheikhs in those countries while neglecting drawing attention to the other aspects related to the issue and facilitating in it. I truly believe that such strictness on women cannot produce for us a generation of women who can perform the duties laid upon their shoulders in all countries and situations with their husbands and others whom circumstances require them to deal with, as they were in the time of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, such as serving guests and feeding them, and going out in battles giving water to the thirsty, treating the wounded, transporting the dead, and perhaps engaging in fighting themselves when necessary. Is it possible for women who were raised on the fear of falling into sin - if she prayed or performed Hajj with her face and hands uncovered - to undertake such actions while wearing Niqab and gloves? No, by my Lord, for that is impossible except by uncovering their faces and hands, and what is not permissible usually might become uncovered from them as the Exalted said: (except what appears thereof). As we will see in some examples witnessing to what women were upon in the time of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: First: From Fatima bint Qais: That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to her: (Authentic/Sahih) "Move to Umm Sharik". Umm Sharik was a rich woman from the Ansar, great in spending in the path of Allah, guests descend upon her. So I said: I will do so. He said: [149]

book_title: The Silencing Rebuttal against those who contradicted the scholars, were strict and fanatical, and obligated women to cover their faces and hands, and made it mandatory, not being convinced by their saying: It is Sunnah and recommended
text: "Do not do so. Umm Sharik is a woman with many guests, so I dislike that your Khimar falls off..." The Hadith. Narrated by Muslim and it is mentioned in its entirety in "Al-Jilbab" (p. 66). Second: From Sahl bin Sa'd who said: (Authentic/Sahih) "When Abu Usayd As-Sa'idi got married, he invited the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and his companions. No one made food for them nor served it to them except his wife Umm Usayd... So his wife was their servant that day while she was the bride." Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim and others and it is extracted in "Adab Al-Zifaf". Third: From Asma bint Abu Bakr who said: (Authentic/Sahih) "Az-Zubair married me and he had no wealth on earth nor slave nor anything other than his horse. She said: So I used to feed his horse and suffice him his provision and groom it and crush date stones for his watering camel and feed it and draw water and sew his leather bucket and knead dough... She said: And I used to transport date stones from Az-Zubair's land - which the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, granted him - on my head, and it was two-thirds of a Farsakh away. She said: So I came one day with the date stones on my head and met the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and with him were a group of his Companions. He called me then said: 'Ikh Ikh' (sound to make camel kneel) to carry me behind him. She said: So I felt shy..." The Hadith. Al-Bukhari (5224), Muslim (7 / 11), Ahmed (6 / 347) and Ibn Sa'd (8 / 250) reported it [150]

book_title: The Silencing Response to those who opposed the scholars, became strict and fanatical, and obligated the woman to cover her face and hands, and made it mandatory, and were not content with their saying: It is a Sunnah and recommended
text: The Fourth: From Jabir: (Authentic) "That the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came to a woman from the Ansar, so she spread [a mat] for him near a Sur -[and the Sur is: Clustered palm trees]- and sprinkled around it, slaughtered a sheep, and made food for him. He ate, and we ate with him. Then he performed ablution for the Zhuhr prayer and prayed. The woman said: 'O Messenger of Allah, we have a leftover from our sheep, would you like dinner?' He said: 'Yes.' So he ate, and we ate, then he prayed Asr and did not perform ablution." Extracted by Abu Ya'la in his "Musnad" (4 / 116 / 2160) and At-Tahawi in "Sharh Al-Ma'ani" (1 / 39) via the path of Muhammad bin Al-Munkadir from him. I say: And its chain is authentic. And Al-Humaidi in his "Musnad" (533 / 1266) via the path of Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil: That he heard Jabir bin Abdullah with a similar narration, more complete than it, and the addition belongs to him. I say: Its chain is Hasan. From this path, Ahmad also extracted it (3 / 374 - 375) similarly without the addition. (Note): The commentator on "Abu Ya'la" expanded excessively in extracting the hadith and attributing it to Abdur-Razzaq, the authors of the Sunan, Ibn Hibban, and others, giving the impression that they all have it with this completeness found in Abu Ya'la, which is not the case. Rather, they have the eating the first time, ablution, then Zhuhr prayer, eating the other time, then Asr prayer without ablution. It is extracted in "Sahih Abi Dawood" (186) [151]

book_title: The Silencing Response to those who opposed the scholars, became strict and fanatical, and obligated the woman to cover her face and hands, and made it mandatory, and were not content with their saying: It is a Sunnah and recommended
text: The Fifth: From Anas who said: (Authentic) "When it was the day of Uhud... I saw Aisha bint Abi Bakr and Umm Sulaym, and they were tucking up their garments, I could see the anklets on their legs (meaning: the anklets), jumping (meaning carrying) water skins on their backs, emptying them into the mouths of the people, then returning to fill them, then coming to empty them into the mouths of the people." Extracted by the two Sheikhs (Bukhari and Muslim). It is in the Book (p. 40). The Sixth: From Ar-Rubay' bint Mu'awwid who said: (Authentic) "We used to go on campaigns with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), giving water to the people, serving them, and returning the wounded and dead to Medina." Extracted by Al-Bukhari (2883) and Ahmad (6 / 358). The Seventh: From Umm Atiyyah who said: (Authentic) "I went on seven campaigns with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). I would stay behind in their camps, make food for them, treat the wounded, and look after the sick." Extracted by Muslim (5 / 199), Ibn Abi Shaybah in "Al-Musannaf" (12 / 525), Ahmad (5 / 84 and 6 / 407), Ibn Sa'd (8 / 455), and Al-Bukhari (324) and similar to it, and At-Tabarani (5 / 55 / 121) [152]

book_title: The Silencing Response to those who opposed the scholars, became strict and fanatical, and obligated the woman to cover her face and hands, and made it mandatory, and were not content with their saying: It is a Sunnah and recommended
text: The Eighth: From Anas: (Authentic) "That Umm Sulaym took a dagger on the day of Hunayn and had it with her. Abu Talha saw her and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, this is Umm Sulaym with a dagger.' The Messenger of Allah said to her: 'What is this dagger?' She said: 'I took it so that if any of the polytheists comes near me, I will rip open his belly with it.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) started laughing... The Hadith." Extracted by Muslim (5 / 196), Ahmad (3 / 112, 190, 198, and 286), Ibn Sa'd (8 / 425), and At-Tabarani (25 / 119 - 120). And Ahmad has another path (3 / 108 - 109 and 279). In a narration by him and At-Tabarani (25 / 123 - 124): (Authentic) "He used to go on campaigns with Umm Sulaym and women from the Ansar accompanying him when he campaigned, so they would provide water and treat the wounded." Authenticated by At-Tirmidhi and Ibn Hibban. It is extracted in "Sahih Abi Dawood" (2284). The Ninth: From Ibn Abbas who said: (Authentic) "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to go on campaigns with women, so they would treat the wounded and be given a share from the booty." Extracted by Muslim and others, and authenticated by At-Tirmidhi. It is extracted in "Al-Irwa" (5 / 69 / 1236) and "Sahih Abi Dawood" (2438 and 2439) [153]

book_title: The Silencing Response to those who opposed the scholars, became strict and fanatical, and obligated the woman to cover her face and hands, and made it mandatory, and were not content with their saying: It is a Sunnah and recommended
text: Then the matter continued in this manner after his death (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Here are some examples available according to our condition of authenticity: The First: From Muhajir Al-Ansari: (Hasan) "That Asma bint Yazid Al-Ansariyyah witnessed Yarmouk with the people and killed seven Romans with the pole of her tent." Extracted by Sa'id bin Mansur in "As-Sunan" (3 / 2 / 307 / 2787) and At-Tabarani in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir" (24 / 157 / 403) with a Hasan chain. The Second: From Khalid bin Sayhan who said: "I witnessed Tustar with Abu Musa, and with us were four women treating the wounded, so he gave them a share." Extracted by Ibn Abi Shaybah (12 / 527) and Al-Bukhari in "At-Tarikh" (2 / 1 / 153) with a chain that tolerates being graded Hasan. The Third: From Abdullah bin Qurt Al-Azdi who said: (Authentic) "I campaigned against the Romans with Khalid bin Al-Walid, and I saw the women of Khalid bin Al-Walid and the women of his companions tucking up their garments, carrying water to the Muhajirin, reciting poetry (Rajaz)." Extracted by Sa'id (3 / 2 / 307 / 2788) with an authentic chain, and he has another weak, disconnected path (2785) [154]

book_title: The Silencing Response to those who opposed the scholars, became strict and fanatical, and obligated the woman to cover her face and hands, and made it mandatory, and were not content with their saying: It is a Sunnah and recommended
text: The Fourth: From Abu Balj Yahya bin Abi Sulaym who said: (Its chain is Jayyid) "I saw Samra bint Nahik - and she had reached the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) - wearing a thick armor and a thick headcover (Khimar), with a whip in her hand disciplining the people, enjoining good and forbidding evil." Extracted by At-Tabarani in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir" (24 / 311 / 785) with a Jayyid chain. Al-Haythami said (9 / 264): And its men are trustworthy (1). I say: These are authentic incidents indicating conclusively the perfection, tolerance, and correct upbringing the women of the Salaf possessed, such that they were able to undertake what was obligatory upon them of cooperating in righteousness, even if that was not originally obligatory upon them. So how would their condition be if reality imposed that upon them, such as self-defense, as Umm Sulaym (may Allah be pleased with her) did when she took a dagger on the day of Hunayn, and similar to what Asma bint Abi Bakr (may Allah be pleased with them both) did
foot_note:
1. (1) I say: At-Tabarani listed her in the biography of this Samra, so she is a Companion as the hadith indicates. Adh-Dhahabi mentioned her in "At-Tajrid" (2 / 278) and said: She reached the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and lived long. As for Al-Hafiz, he referred in her biography in (The First Section) to (The Third Section), then forgot and did not mention her in it or elsewhere 
[155].

book_title: The Silencing Response to those who opposed the scholars, became strict and fanatical, and obligated the woman to cover her face and hands, and made it mandatory, and were not content with their saying: It is a Sunnah and recommended
text: She is the one whom the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) disciplined with his previous hadith: "...it is not correct that anything be seen of her except her face and hands." For Ibn Sa'd narrated (8 / 253) with an authentic chain: (Authentic) "That Asma bint Abi Bakr took a dagger during the time of Sa'id bin Al-Aas for thieves, and they had settled in Medina, and she used to put it under her head." All of that is an effect of the Prophet's (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) upbringing of them on the tolerant Hanifiyya (true monotheism), which has neither excess nor negligence. So they were as Allah Almighty said: {You are the best nation produced [as an example] for mankind. You enjoin what is right and forbid what is wrong and believe in Allah} [Al Imran: 110], and He said: {And thus we have made you a just community that you will be witnesses over the people and the Messenger will be a witness over you} [Al-Baqarah: 143]. Upon this noble Prophetic methodology, the Sheikhs and preachers must raise people, men and women. They will not be able to do that unless they acquaint themselves with the authentic Sunnah and Prophetic biography, which includes: his saying, action, approval, and what our righteous predecessors were upon from what is authentically reported from them. For the Fiqh (understanding) of a scholar is not upright except with all of this, seeking help in that from the sayings of the Mujtahid Imams and the verifying scholars, otherwise he deviates from the truth and the path of the believers. How excellent is Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah (may Allah have mercy on him) when he drew attention to this - and it is among his precious gems which I have not seen from others - in his previous statement (p. 48): "And what is transmitted from the Salaf and the scholars requires knowledge of the establishment of its wording and its indication, just as what is transmitted from Allah and His Messenger requires that." [156]

book_title: The Silencing Response to those who opposed the scholars, became strict and fanatical, and obligated the woman to cover her face and hands, and made it mandatory, and were not content with their saying: It is a Sunnah and recommended
text: My belief is that if the scholars adhered to this methodology, much of the existing disagreement between them would disappear, provided they are sincere to Allah, Blessed and Exalted, in seeking the truth and avoiding blind imitation of Madhhabs, fathers, and grandfathers, which many people are afflicted with today. And Allah is the One sought for help. Among the best things to conclude my book with is the expiation of the gathering (Kaffarat al-Majlis): Glory be to You, O Allah, and with Your praise, I bear witness that there is no deity but You, I ask Your forgiveness and repent to You. And may Allah send blessings upon Muhammad, the unlettered Prophet, and upon his family and companions and grant them peace. Amman, Monday evening, 26 Dhu al-Hijjah, year 1411. Written by: Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani Abu Abdur-Rahman [157]

book_title: The Silencing Response to those who opposed the scholars, became strict and fanatical, and obligated the woman to cover her face and hands, and made it mandatory, and were not content with their saying: It is a Sunnah and recommended
text: And sometimes they say: That was before the revelation of the verse of Hijab (1) and that she was young. At-Tuwayjiri quoted this with admiration saying (p. 154): "And there is no addition to it." This is from his stubbornness and denial of scientific facts, for he knows that Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar has invalidated these sayings and proven that this was years after Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) reached puberty. So you must see "Fath al-Bari" (1 / 550 and 443 - 445). From that is their interpretation of the hadith of Fatimah bint Qais (may Allah be pleased with her) - as previously explained (p. 46 - 47) - for it indicates the permissibility of her looking at foreign guests and their looking at her, meaning: at her face. Therefore, Al-Qurtubi in his "Tafsir" made it specific to the generality of His saying Almighty: {And tell the believing women to reduce [some] of their vision} [An-Nur: 31]. With it and the hadith of Aisha, the senior Hanbali scholars from the Maqdisis and others argued - as preceded (p. 66) - for the permissibility of a woman looking at other than the 'Awrah of a man. This might be among the agreed-upon matters provided desire is absent. For I saw Al-Hafiz Ibn al-Qattan saying in his book (Folio 64 / 1): "There is no disagreement I know of regarding the permissibility of a woman looking at the face of a man whatever he may be, if she does not intend pleasure and does not fear temptation, like a man looking at the faces of boys and beardless youths if
foot_note:
1. (1) This means according to scholars the abrogation of specific evidences by a general evidence, and this is something no scholar of the fundamental jurisprudential scientific rules says. The invalidation of this saying will come in the Fifth Shubhah (Doubt) " (p. 122) 
[166].
